The	O
project	O
area	O
is	O
located	O
29km	O
north	O
of	O
Leonora	O
and	O
can	O

12km.	O

purchase.	O

and	O
Die	O
area	O
is	O

Archaean	O
aged	O
Yilgarn	O
Craton	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia	O
and	O
lies	O

Kurnalpi	O

of	O

Eastern	O
Goldfields	O

The	O
Eastern	O
Goldfields	O
Superterrane	O
comprises	O
elongated	O
belts	O
of	O
deformed	O
and	O
metamorphosed	O

intruded	O
by	O
granitoid	O

and	O

that	O
trend	O
predominantly	O
north-northwest.	O

and	O
Die	O
occurs	O
in	O
a	O

zone	O
of	O

and	O

is	O

of	O

Background	O

OZZ	O
Resources	O

July	O
2021	O
and	O
is	O
focused	O

an	O

program	O
across	O
its	O

of	O
projects	O

program	O
planned	O
this	O
year.	O

Leonora	O
Project	O

Mt	O
Davis	O
project	O
,	O

5	O
Limited	O

4.1Moz	O
King	O
of	O

gold	O

was	O

in	O

Forward-Looking	O
Statements	O
This	O
document	O
may	O
include	O
forward-looking	O
statements.	O
Forward-looking	O
statements	O
include	O
,	O
but	O
are	O
not	O
limited	O
to	O
,	O
statements	O
concerning	O
Kingwest	O
Resources	O
Limited	O
’	O
s	O
planned	O
exploration	O
program	O
and	O
other	O
statements	O
that	O
are	O
not	O
historical	O
facts.	O
When	O
used	O
in	O
this	O
document	O
,	O
the	O
words	O
such	O
as	O
"could	O
,	O
"	O
"plan	O
,	O
"	O
"expect	O
,	O
"	O
"intend	O
,	O
"	O
"may	O
”	O
,	O
"potential	O
,	O
"	O
"should	O
,	O
"	O
and	O
similar	O
expressions	O
are	O
forward-looking	O
statements.	O
Although	O
Kingwest	O
believes	O
that	O
its	O
expectations	O
reflected	O
in	O
these	O
forward-	O
looking	O
statements	O
are	O
reasonable	O
,	O
such	O
statements	O
involve	O
risks	O
and	O
uncertainties	O
and	O
no	O
assurance	O
can	O
be	O
given	O
that	O
further	O
exploration	O
will	O
result	O
in	O
the	O
estimation	O
of	O
a	O
Mineral	O
Resource.	O

Person	O

to	O

results	O

ABOUT	O
THE	O
MGP	O
and	O
GGP	O
Menzies	O
is	O
one	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia	O
’	O
s	O
major	O
historic	O
gold	O
fields.	O
Located	O
130km	O
north	O
of	O
the	O
globally	O
significant	O
gold	O
deposits	O
of	O
Kalgoorlie	O
(	O
Figure	O
5	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
MGP	O
covers	O
a	O
contiguous	O
land	O
package	O
over	O
a	O
strike	O
length	O
in	O
excess	O
of	O
15km.	O
Within	O
the	O
MGP	O
a	O
series	O
of	O
structurally	O
controlled	O
high-grade	O
gold	O
deposits	O
have	O
been	O
historically	O
mined	O
and	O
display	O
extensive	O
exploration	O
potential	O
for	O
high-grade	O
extensions.	O
Modern	O
exploration	O
since	O
closure	O
over	O
20	O
years	O
ago	O
has	O
been	O
limited.	O
The	O
MGP	O
has	O
recorded	O
historical	O
production	O
of	O
643	O
,	O
200	O
oz	O
@	O
22.5g/t	O
Au1	O
from	O
underground	O
(	O
U/G	O
)	O
between	O
1895	O
and	O
1943	O
plus	O
145	O
,	O
000	O
oz	O
@	O
2.6g/t	O
Au1	O
open	O
cut	O
between	O
1995	O
and	O
1999	O
,	O
for	O
a	O
total	O
of	O
787	O
,	O
200	O
oz	O
@	O
18.9g/t1	O
Au.	O
The	O
MGP	O
is	O
hosted	O
along	O
the	O
Menzies	O
Shear	O
Zone.	O
All	O
deposits	O
lie	O
within	O
granted	O
Mining	O
Leases	O
and	O
are	O
100%	O
owned	O
by	O
KWR.	O
Current	O
mineral	O
resources	O
total	O
320	O
,	O
000	O
oz	O
@	O
2.1g/t	O
Au	O
(	O
Table	O
3	O
)	O
.	O

Importantly	O
the	O
MGP	O
lies	O
on	O
the	O
Goldfields	O
Highway	O
,	O
has	O
power	O
and	O
water	O
and	O
is	O
within	O
trucking	O
distance	O
of	O
numerous	O
Gold	O
Processing	O
Plants.	O
The	O
GGP	O
is	O
located	O
approximately	O
40km	O
south	O
of	O
KWR	O
’	O
s	O
Menzies	O
Gold	O
Project	O
(	O
MGP	O
)	O
and	O
90km	O
north	O
of	O
Kalgoorlie.	O
The	O
GGP	O
is	O
a	O
contiguous	O
land	O
package	O
covering	O
approximately	O
125	O
square	O
km	O
over	O
a	O
strike	O
length	O
in	O
excess	O
of	O
25km.	O
Within	O
the	O
GGP	O
a	O
series	O
of	O
structurally	O
controlled	O
high-grade	O
gold	O
deposits	O
have	O
been	O
historically	O
mined	O
and	O
these	O
display	O
extensive	O
exploration	O
potential	O
for	O
high-grade	O
extensions.	O
Modern	O
exploration	O
since	O
closure	O
of	O
the	O
mines	O
over	O
20	O
years	O
ago	O
has	O
been	O
limited.	O
The	O
GGP	O
sits	O
within	O
the	O
Bardoc	O
Tectonic	O
Zone	O
(	O
BTZ	O
)	O
which	O
extends	O
south	O
to	O
Kalgoorlie	O
and	O
north	O
to	O
Menzies.	O
All	O
resources	O
lie	O
within	O
granted	O
Mining	O
Leases	O
and	O
are	O
100%	O
owned	O
by	O
KWR.	O

75km	O
north	O

Table	O
1	O
Section	O
1	O
Sampling	O
Techniques	O
and	O
Data	O
Criteria	O
JORC	O
Code	O
explanation	O
Commentary	O
Sampling	O
•	O

Nature	O
and	O
quality	O
of	O
sampling	O
(	O
eg	O
cut	O
•	O

The	O
H2	O
2020	O
drilling	O
program	O
by	O
Kingwest	O
techniques	O
channels	O
,	O
random	O
chips	O
,	O
or	O
specific	O
specialised	O
Resources	O
(	O
KWR	O
)	O
includes	O
Reverse	O
Circulation	O
industry	O
standard	O
measurement	O
tools	O
(	O
RC	O
)	O
drilling.	O
The	O
majority	O
of	O
drill	O
holes	O
have	O
appropriate	O
to	O
the	O
minerals	O
under	O
a	O
dip	O
of	O
-60	O
°	O

towards	O

SOUTH	O
AUSTRALIAN	O
EXPLORATION	O
WILCHERRY	O
PROJECT	O
(	O
100%	O
)	O
The	O
Wilcherry	O
Project	O
is	O
located	O
within	O
the	O
southern	O
region	O
of	O
the	O
Gawler	O
Craton	O
(	O

1	O

40	O
km	O
north	O
of	O
Kimba	O
in	O
South	O
Australia.	O

comprises	O
seven	O
exploration	O
licences	O
covering	O
1	O
,	O
484	O
km2	O
which	O
are	O
prospective	O
for	O
gold	O
and	O
base	O
metals.	O
Figure1.	O
Wilcherry	O
Project	O
location	O
Weednanna	O
gold-iron	O
Deposit	O

is	O
the	O
most	O
advanced	O

and	O

at	O
the	O

a	O
250	O

on	O

margins	O
of	O
,	O
ironstone	O
and	O
magnetite-rich	O
skarn.	O
In	O
late	O
2019	O
,	O
Alliance	O
reviewed	O
the	O
iron	O
ore	O
potential	O
of	O
Weednanna	O
and	O
commenced	O
selectively	O
analysing	O
Alliance	O
gold	O
drilling	O
sample	O
pulps	O
associated	O
with	O
ironstone	O
and	O
magnetite	O
skarn	O
for	O
an	O
extended	O
iron	O
ore	O
suite	O
of	O
elements	O
and	O
compounds	O
consisting	O
of	O

,	O

,	O

O	O
,	O

,	O

,	O

,	O

,	O
2	O
2	O
3	O

,	O
K	O
O	O
,	O
Na	O
O	O
,	O
TiO	O
,	O
Cu	O
,	O
Ni	O
,	O
Co	O
,	O
Cr	O
,	O
Pb	O
,	O
Zn	O
,	O
As	O
,	O
Sn	O
,	O
Sr	O
,	O

,	O
Ba	O
,	O
V	O
,	O

and	O
LOI.	O
Where	O
possible	O
1m	O
split	O
2	O
2	O
2	O
samples	O
were	O

,	O

in	O

1m	O

were	O

,	O
4m	O
composite	O
scoop	O

were	O

5All	O
significant	O
iron	O
assay	O
results	O
were	O
reported	O
to	O
the	O
ASX	O
in	O
an	O
announcement	O
dated	O
31	O
August	O
2020	O
in	O
preparation	O
for	O
estimation	O
of	O
an	O
iron	O
mineral	O
resource.	O
Alliance	O
has	O
focussed	O
on	O
producing	O
a	O
Direct	O
Shipping	O
Ore	O
(	O
DSO	O
)	O
without	O
the	O
need	O
for	O
onsite	O
beneficiation.	O
Project	O
Work	O
A	O
small	O
weather	O
station	O
and	O
four	O
dust	O
monitoring	O
stations	O
were	O
installed	O
at	O
Weednanna	O
during	O
the	O
year	O
to	O
collect	O
baseline	O
environmental	O
data	O
to	O
build	O
the	O
pre-mining	O
environmental	O
model	O
for	O
the	O
planned	O
mining	O
area.	O
Data	O
collection	O
and	O
analysis	O
continued	O
throughout	O
the	O
year	O
building	O
our	O
baseline	O
model	O
and	O
shall	O
continue	O
throughout	O
the	O
life	O
of	O
the	O
project	O
with	O
data	O
recorded	O
used	O
to	O
manage	O
mine	O
outputs	O
against	O
the	O
stated	O
performance.	O
Alliance	O
has	O
commenced	O
a	O
two-stage	O
research	O
project	O
with	O
the	O
CSIRO	O
to	O
better	O
understand	O
the	O
paragenesis	O
of	O
the	O
Weednanna	O
Au-Fe	O
deposit	O
and	O
develop	O
mineralogical	O
or	O
geochemical	O
tools	O
to	O
assist	O
with	O
targeting	O
future	O
exploration.	O
Stage	O
1	O
of	O
the	O
project	O
consists	O
of	O
mapping	O
the	O
distribution	O
of	O
alteration	O
mineralogy	O
around	O
the	O
deposit	O
and	O
linking	O
this	O
to	O
geochemistry	O
and	O
age	O
dating	O
granitic	O
rocks.	O
This	O
phase	O
of	O
research	O
will	O
be	O
complete	O
before	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
2021.	O
Stage	O
2	O
will	O
analyse	O
core	O
collected	O
from	O
6	O
diamond	O
holes	O
to	O
link	O
the	O
mineralogy	O
and	O
geochemistry	O
to	O
the	O
gold	O
and	O
iron	O
mineralising	O
events	O
and	O
determine	O
the	O
age	O
of	O
mineralisation.	O
This	O
work	O
will	O
continue	O
through	O
2022.	O
Evaluation	O
of	O
alternative	O
/	O

energy	O

for	O

Weednanna	O

,	O

and	O
is	O

to	O

19	O
November	O
2020.	O

material	O
assumptions	O
and	O
technical	O
parameters	O
underpinning	O
the	O
mineral	O
resource	O

in	O

announcement	O
of	O
19	O
November	O
2020	O
continue	O
to	O
apply	O
and	O
have	O
not	O
materially	O
changed.	O
Ore	O
Reserves	O

Company	O
did	O
not	O
hold	O
any	O
Ore	O
Reserves	O
at	O
30	O
June	O
2021.	O

Against	O
Previous	O
Year	O

Weednanna	O

Mineral	O

(	O

-	O

Indicated	O
590	O
,	O
000	O
4.6	O
88	O
,	O
000	O
Inferred	O
507	O
,	O
000	O
5.7	O
93	O
,	O
000	O
Total	O
1	O
,	O
097	O
,	O
000	O
5.1	O
181	O
,	O
000	O
The	O
reported	O
Mineral	O
Resource	O
is	O
that	O
proportion	O
of	O
gold	O
contained	O
within	O
$2	O
,	O
000	O
AUD	O
pit	O
shells	O
(	O
>0.5	O
g/t	O
gold	O
)	O
and	O
>2.0	O
g/t	O
gold	O
underground	O
potential.	O
The	O
gold	O
mineral	O
resource	O
reported	O
at	O
30	O
June	O
2021	O
contains	O
data	O
from	O
275	O
new	O
drill	O
holes	O
and	O
is	O
calculated	O
with	O
a	O
higher	O
level	O
of	O
geological	O
confidence	O
,	O
represented	O
by	O
a	O
24	O
%	O
increase	O
in	O
the	O
Measured	O
and	O
Indicated	O
resource	O
categories	O
compared	O
to	O
the	O
previous	O
year.	O
A	O
16%	O
decrease	O
in	O
total	O
contained	O
ounces	O
from	O
the	O
previous	O
year	O
is	O
largely	O
attributed	O
to	O
an	O
18	O
%	O
decrease	O
in	O
the	O
average	O
density	O
of	O
the	O
deposit.	O
The	O
previous	O
mineral	O
resource	O
,	O
completed	O
in	O
2018	O
,	O
estimated	O
average	O
density	O
values	O
for	O
each	O
gold	O
domain	O
using	O
a	O
database	O
consisting	O
of	O
1	O
,	O
123	O
specific	O
gravity	O
measurements.	O
However	O
,	O
recognising	O
the	O
heterogeneous	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
skarn-altered	O
meta-	O
sediments	O
that	O
host	O
much	O
of	O
the	O
gold	O
at	O
Weednanna	O
,	O
Alliance	O
continued	O
to	O
collect	O
density	O
measurements	O
and	O
increased	O
the	O
size	O
of	O
the	O
density	O
database	O
to	O
9	O
,	O
715	O
specific	O
gravity	O
measurements.	O
The	O
outcome	O
of	O
this	O
work	O
resulted	O
in	O
a	O
material	O
decrease	O
in	O
the	O
average	O
density	O
of	O
the	O
deposit	O
from	O
3.58	O
SG	O
to	O
2.95	O
SG.	O
The	O
net	O
outcome	O
is	O
a	O
21	O
,	O
000	O
ounce	O
gain	O
in	O
high	O
geological	O
confidence	O
Measured	O
and	O
Indicated	O
Resources	O
and	O
a	O
49	O
,	O
500	O
ounce	O
reduction	O
in	O
low	O
geological	O
confidence	O
Inferred	O
Resources.	O
The	O
Company	O
had	O
not	O
completed	O
an	O

for	O
the	O

STATEMENT	O

Gray	O

is	O

to	O
the	O
style	O

results	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
current	O
stage	O
of	O
the	O
Group's	O
project	O
;	O
and	O
•	O

Reviewing	O
public	O
(	O
ASX	O
)	O
announcements	O
and	O
minutes	O
of	O
directors	O
’	O
meetings	O
to	O
ensure	O
that	O
the	O
Group	O
had	O
not	O
decided	O
to	O
discontinue	O
activities	O
in	O
any	O
of	O
its	O
areas	O
of	O
interest.	O
59Other	O
information	O
The	O
directors	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
the	O
other	O
information.	O
The	O
other	O
information	O
comprises	O
the	O
information	O
in	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
annual	O
report	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2021	O
,	O
but	O
does	O
not	O
include	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
and	O
the	O
auditor	O
’	O
s	O
report	O
thereon	O
,	O
which	O
we	O
obtained	O
prior	O
to	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
this	O
auditor	O
’	O
s	O
report	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
Chairman	O
’	O
s	O
address	O
,	O
review	O
of	O
operations	O
and	O
tenement	O
schedule	O
reports	O
,	O
which	O
are	O
expected	O
to	O
be	O
made	O
available	O
to	O
us	O
after	O
that	O
date.	O
Our	O
opinion	O
on	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
does	O
not	O
cover	O
the	O
other	O
information	O
and	O
we	O
do	O
not	O
express	O
any	O
form	O
of	O
assurance	O
conclusion	O
thereon.	O
In	O
connection	O
with	O
our	O
audit	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
,	O
our	O
responsibility	O
is	O
to	O
read	O
the	O
other	O
information	O
and	O
,	O
in	O
doing	O
so	O
,	O
consider	O
whether	O
the	O
other	O
information	O
is	O
materially	O
inconsistent	O
with	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
or	O
our	O
knowledge	O
obtained	O
in	O
the	O
audit	O
or	O
otherwise	O
appears	O
to	O
be	O
materially	O
misstated.	O
If	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
work	O
we	O
have	O
performed	O
,	O
we	O
conclude	O
that	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
material	O
misstatement	O
of	O
this	O
other	O
information	O
,	O
we	O
are	O
required	O
to	O
report	O
that	O
fact.	O
We	O
have	O
nothing	O
to	O
report	O
in	O
this	O
regard.	O
When	O
we	O
read	O
the	O
Chairman	O
’	O
s	O
address	O
,	O
review	O
of	O
operations	O
and	O
tenement	O
schedule	O
reports	O
,	O
if	O
we	O
conclude	O
that	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
material	O
misstatement	O
therein	O
,	O
we	O
are	O
required	O
to	O
communicate	O
the	O
matter	O
to	O
the	O
directors	O
and	O
will	O
request	O
that	O
it	O
is	O
corrected.	O
If	O
it	O
is	O
not	O
corrected	O
,	O
we	O
will	O
seek	O
to	O
have	O
the	O
matter	O
appropriately	O
brought	O
to	O
the	O
attention	O
of	O
users	O
for	O
whom	O
our	O
report	O
is	O
prepared.	O
Responsibilities	O
of	O
the	O
directors	O
for	O
the	O
Financial	O
Report	O
The	O
directors	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
that	O
gives	O
a	O
TRUE	O
and	O
fair	O
view	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
Australian	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
and	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001	O
and	O
for	O
such	O
internal	O
control	O
as	O
the	O
directors	O
determine	O
is	O
necessary	O
to	O
enable	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
that	O
gives	O
a	O
TRUE	O
and	O
fair	O
view	O
and	O
is	O
free	O
from	O
material	O
misstatement	O
,	O
whether	O
due	O
to	O
fraud	O
or	O
error.	O
In	O
preparing	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
,	O
the	O
directors	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
assessing	O
the	O
ability	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
to	O
continue	O
as	O
a	O
going	O
concern	O
,	O
disclosing	O
,	O
as	O
applicable	O
,	O
matters	O
related	O
to	O
going	O
concern	O
and	O
using	O
the	O
going	O
concern	O
basis	O
of	O
accounting	O
unless	O
the	O
directors	O
either	O
intend	O
to	O
liquidate	O
the	O
Group	O
or	O
to	O
cease	O
operations	O
,	O
or	O
has	O
no	O
realistic	O
alternative	O
but	O
to	O
do	O
so.	O
Auditor	O
’	O
s	O
responsibilities	O
for	O
the	O
audit	O
of	O
the	O
Financial	O
Report	O
Our	O
objectives	O
are	O
to	O
obtain	O
reasonable	O
assurance	O
about	O
whether	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
as	O
a	O
whole	O
is	O
free	O
from	O
material	O
misstatement	O
,	O
whether	O
due	O
to	O
fraud	O
or	O
error	O
,	O
and	O
to	O
issue	O
an	O
auditor	O
’	O
s	O
report	O
that	O
includes	O
our	O
opinion.	O
Reasonable	O
assurance	O
is	O
a	O
high	O
level	O
of	O
assurance	O
,	O
but	O
is	O
not	O
a	O
guarantee	O
that	O
an	O
audit	O
conducted	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
Australian	O
Auditing	O
Standards	O
will	O
always	O
detect	O
a	O
material	O
misstatement	O
when	O
it	O
exists.	O
Misstatements	O
can	O
arise	O
from	O
fraud	O
or	O
error	O
and	O
are	O
considered	O
material	O
if	O
,	O
individually	O
or	O
in	O
the	O
aggregate	O
,	O
they	O
could	O
reasonably	O
be	O
expected	O
to	O
influence	O
the	O
economic	O
decisions	O
of	O
users	O
taken	O
on	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
this	O
financial	O
report.	O

Margaret	O

)	O

ABOUT	O
LATITUDE	O
CONSOLIDATED	O
Latitude	O
Consolidated	O
(	O
ASX	O
:	O
LCD	O
)	O
is	O
a	O
junior	O
gold	O
explorer	O
with	O
a	O
portfolio	O
of	O
exploration	O
projects	O
across	O
Western	O
Australia	O
and	O
South	O
Australia.	O
Latitude	O
’	O
s	O
flagship	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Project	O
has	O
a	O
combined	O
343km	O
²	O

landholding	O
in	O
the	O
prolific	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Fields	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia	O
and	O
hosts	O
a	O
large	O
high	O
grade	O
1.1Moz	O
Mineral	O
Resource.	O
The	O
company	O
is	O
actively	O
exploring	O
on	O
this	O
tenure	O
while	O
also	O
progressing	O
mining	O
studies	O
to	O
determine	O
the	O
best	O
pathway	O
to	O
production.	O
The	O
Circle	O
Valley	O
project	O
in	O
southern	O
WA	O
sits	O
in	O
the	O
Albany	O
Fraser	O
mobile	O
belt.	O
This	O
belt	O
is	O
also	O
home	O
to	O
the	O
Tropicana	O
gold	O
mine	O
(	O
3Moz	O
past	O
production	O
)	O
.	O

Primary	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
has	O
been	O
identified	O
in	O
two	O
separate	O
locations	O
at	O
Circle	O
Valley	O
and	O
presents	O
an	O
exciting	O
exploration	O
opportunity	O
for	O
Latitude.	O
The	O
Skye	O
Gold	O
Project	O
in	O
the	O
Gawler	O
Craton	O
in	O
South	O
Australia	O
is	O
located	O
in	O
a	O
region	O
known	O
for	O
plunge-continuous	O
high-grade	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
such	O
as	O
that	O
seen	O
at	O
nearby	O
Challenger	O
Gold	O
Deposit	O
(	O
1.2Moz	O
past	O
production	O
)	O
.	O

exploration	O
prize	O
in	O

Province	O
terrain	O
can	O
be	O
significant	O
,	O

high-value	O
,	O
high-grade	O
discoveries	O
in	O
the	O
district	O
having	O
a	O

for	O
excellent	O
down-plunge	O
continuity	O
of	O
mineralised	O
shoots.	O
Global	O

Resource	O

to	O
+1.1	O

Ounces	O
”	O
.	O

is	O

29Environmental	O
regulation	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
and	O
its	O
activities	O
in	O
Australia	O
and	O
overseas	O
are	O
subject	O
to	O
environmental	O
regulations.	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
’	O
Prominent	O
Hill	O
operations	O
,	O
Carrapateena	O
project	O
,	O
Australian	O
exploration	O
activities	O
and	O
concentrate	O
shipping	O
activities	O
operate	O
under	O
various	O
licences	O
and	O
permits	O
under	O
Commonwealth	O
,	O
state	O
and	O
territory	O
laws	O
,	O
in	O
addition	O
to	O
the	O
licensing	O
and	O
permit	O
arrangements	O
which	O
apply	O
to	O
its	O
overseas	O
activities.	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
’	O
Antas	O
operations	O
are	O
also	O
subject	O
to	O
environmental	O
regulations	O
under	O
legislation	O
in	O
Brazil.	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
regularly	O
monitors	O
its	O
compliance	O
with	O
licenses	O
and	O
permits	O
in	O
various	O
ways	O
,	O
including	O
through	O
its	O
own	O
environmental	O
audits	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
those	O
conducted	O
by	O
regulatory	O
authorities	O
and	O
other	O
third	O
parties.	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
uses	O
a	O
documented	O
process	O
to	O
classify	O
and	O
report	O
any	O
exceedance	O
of	O
a	O
licence	O
or	O
permit	O
condition	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
any	O
incident	O
reportable	O
to	O
the	O
relevant	O
authorities.	O
All	O
instances	O
of	O
reportable	O
environmental	O
non-compliance	O
and	O
significant	O
incidents	O
are	O
reviewed	O
by	O
the	O

and	O
the	O
Sustainability	O
Committee	O
of	O
the	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Board	O
of	O
Directors	O
as	O
a	O
part	O
of	O
this	O
process.	O
A	O
formal	O
report	O
is	O
also	O
prepared	O
to	O
identify	O
the	O
factors	O
that	O
contributed	O
to	O
the	O
incident	O
or	O
non-compliance	O
and	O
the	O
actions	O
taken	O
to	O
prevent	O
any	O
reoccurrence.	O

the	O
year	O
,	O
OZ	O

submitted	O
the	O

and	O

2.2	O
Remuneration	O
consultants	O
The	O
Board	O
of	O
Directors	O
and	O
the	O
People	O
&	O
Remuneration	O
Committee	O
seek	O
and	O
consider	O
advice	O
from	O
independent	O

to	O
ensure	O
that	O
they	O
have	O
all	O
of	O
the	O
relevant	O
information	O
at	O
their	O
disposal	O
to	O
determine	O
executive	O
KMP	O
remuneration.	O
Remuneration	O
consultant	O
engagement	O
is	O
governed	O
by	O
internal	O
protocols	O
that	O
set	O
the	O
parameters	O
around	O
the	O
interaction	O
between	O
management	O
and	O
consultants	O
to	O
minimise	O
the	O
risk	O
of	O
any	O
undue	O
influence	O
and	O
ensure	O
compliance	O
with	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001.	O
PROTOCOLS	O
Under	O
the	O
protocols	O
adopted	O
by	O
the	O
Board	O
and	O
the	O
People	O
&	O
Remuneration	O
Committee	O
:	O
/	O
remuneration	O
consultants	O
are	O
engaged	O
by	O
and	O
report	O
directly	O
to	O
the	O
Board	O
or	O
the	O
People	O
&	O
Remuneration	O
Committee	O
/	O
the	O
committee	O
must	O
,	O
in	O
deciding	O
whether	O
to	O
approve	O
the	O
engagement	O
,	O
have	O
regard	O
to	O
any	O
potential	O
conflicts	O
of	O
interest	O
including	O
factors	O
that	O
may	O
influence	O
independence	O
such	O
as	O
previous	O
and	O
future	O
work	O
performed	O
by	O
the	O
Committee	O
and	O
any	O
relationships	O
that	O
exist	O
between	O
any	O
executive	O
KMP	O
and	O
the	O
consultant	O
/	O
communication	O
between	O
the	O
remuneration	O
consultants	O
and	O
executive	O
KMP	O
is	O
restricted	O
to	O
minimise	O
the	O
risk	O
of	O
undue	O
influence	O
on	O
the	O
remuneration	O
consultant	O
/	O
where	O
the	O
consultant	O
is	O
also	O
engaged	O
to	O
perform	O
work	O
that	O
does	O
not	O
involve	O
the	O
provision	O
of	O
a	O
remuneration	O
recommendation	O
,	O
prior	O
approval	O
of	O
the	O
Board	O
or	O
People	O
&	O
Remuneration	O
Committee	O
must	O
be	O
obtained	O
in	O
certain	O
circumstances	O
where	O
the	O
consultant	O
continues	O
to	O
be	O
engaged	O
to	O
provide	O
remuneration	O
recommendations.	O

Board	O
and	O
the	O
People	O
&	O
Remuneration	O
Committee	O
use	O
remuneration	O
consultants	O
’	O
advice	O
and	O
recommendations	O
from	O
time	O
to	O
time.	O

Board	O

its	O
decisions	O
after	O
it	O
considers	O
the	O
issues	O
and	O
the	O
advice	O
from	O
the	O
People	O
&	O
Remuneration	O
Committee	O
and	O
consultants.	O
During	O
2018	O
,	O

and	O

to	O

the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
executive	O

)	O
What	O
is	O
included	O
in	O
total	O
fixed	O
remuneration?	O
An	O
executive	O
KMP	O
total	O
fixed	O
remuneration	O
comprises	O
salary	O
and	O
certain	O
other	O
benefits	O
(	O
including	O
statutory	O
superannuation	O
contributions	O
)	O
that	O
may	O
be	O
taken	O
in	O
an	O
agreed	O
form	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
cash	O
,	O
leased	O
motor	O
vehicles	O
and	O
additional	O
superannuation	O
,	O
provided	O
that	O
no	O
extra	O
cost	O
is	O

by	O
the	O
Company	O
for	O
these	O

is	O

reviewed	O
annually.	O

&	O

of	O
executive	O

(	O

)	O

does	O

link	O
between	O
pay	O
and	O
performance.	O

targets	O

of	O

Non-executive	O
Director	O
remuneration	O
policy	O
Non-executive	O
Director	O
(	O
NED	O
)	O
remuneration	O
is	O
reviewed	O
annually	O
by	O
the	O
Board.	O
NEDs	O
receive	O
a	O
fixed	O
fee	O
remuneration	O
consisting	O
of	O
a	O
base	O
fee	O
rate	O
and	O
additional	O
fees	O
for	O
committee	O
roles.	O
Consistent	O
with	O
best	O
practice	O
,	O
NEDs	O
do	O
not	O
receive	O
any	O
form	O
of	O
equity	O
incentive	O
entitlement	O
,	O
bonuses	O
,	O
options	O
,	O
other	O
incentive	O
payments	O
or	O
retirement	O

$2	O
,	O

,	O
000	O
in	O
total.	O

Executive	O

SUSTAINABILITY	O
IN	O
PRACTICE	O
SUSTAINABLE	O
WASTE	O
MANAGEMENT	O
AT	O
PROMINENT	O
HILL	O
Prominent	O
Hill	O
runs	O
an	O
extensive	O
recycling	O
program.	O
This	O
recycling	O
program	O
diverts	O
many	O
varying	O
waste	O
streams	O
from	O
landfill	O
resulting	O
in	O
50%	O
of	O
non-mining	O
waste	O
generated	O
being	O
either	O
recycled	O
or	O
reused.	O
In	O
late	O
2018	O
a	O
trial	O
of	O
biobin	O
technology	O
was	O
implemented	O
to	O
further	O
this	O
philosophy.	O
The	O
biobins	O
collect	O
food	O
waste	O
generated	O
by	O
the	O
Camp	O
kitchen	O
facilities	O
within	O
a	O
sealed	O
bin	O
unit.	O
This	O
waste	O
is	O
then	O
sent	O
off	O
site	O
utilising	O
courier	O
backloads	O
to	O
Adelaide	O
where	O
it	O
is	O
processed	O
into	O
compost	O
and	O
fertilisers.	O
This	O
process	O
has	O
the	O
additional	O
benefit	O
of	O
providing	O
the	O

How	O
the	O
Standard	O
Defines	O
Limited	O
Assurance	O
and	O
Material	O
Misstatement	O
The	O
procedures	O
performed	O
in	O
a	O
limited	O
assurance	O
engagement	O
vary	O
in	O
nature	O
and	O
timing	O
from	O
,	O
and	O
are	O
less	O
in	O
extent	O
than	O
for	O
a	O
reasonable	O
assurance	O
engagement.	O
Consequently	O
the	O
level	O
of	O
assurance	O
obtained	O
in	O
a	O
limited	O
assurance	O
engagement	O
is	O
substantially	O
lower	O
than	O
the	O
assurance	O
that	O
would	O
have	O
been	O
obtained	O
had	O
a	O
reasonable	O
assurance	O
engagement	O
been	O
performed.	O
Misstatements	O
,	O
including	O
omissions	O
,	O
are	O
considered	O
material	O
if	O
,	O
individually	O
or	O
in	O
the	O
aggregate	O
,	O
they	O
could	O
reasonably	O
be	O
expected	O
to	O
influence	O
relevant	O
decisions	O
of	O
the	O
Directors	O
of	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Ltd.	O
Use	O
of	O
this	O
Assurance	O

has	O
been	O

for	O

Directors	O
of	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Ltd	O
for	O
the	O
purpose	O
of	O

assurance	O
conclusion	O
on	O
the	O
Selected	O
Sustainability	O
Information	O
and	O
may	O
not	O

for	O
another	O
purpose.	O

any	O

OZ	O
Minerals	O
Ltd	O

of	O
Comprehensive	O
Income	O
has	O
been	O

to	O
better	O
represent	O
how	O
the	O
business	O

managed.	O
This	O

no	O

on	O
the	O

performance	O
1.	O
Operating	O
segments	O
Segment	O
Principal	O
activities	O
Prominent	O
Hill	O
Mining	O
and	O
processing	O
high	O
grade	O
underground	O

containing	O
copper	O
,	O
gold	O
and	O
silver	O
along	O
with	O
open	O
pit	O
ore	O
from	O
stockpiles.	O

Prominent	O
Hill	O
mine	O
is	O
located	O
in	O
the	O
Gawler	O
Craton	O
of	O
South	O
Australia.	O

Prominent	O
Hill	O
mine	O
generates	O

from	O
the	O

of	O
concentrate	O
containing	O
copper	O
,	O

and	O

Carrapateena	O

and	O

Carrapateena	O
project	O

i	O

containing	O
copper	O
and	O
gold	O
to	O
customers	O
in	O
the	O
United	O
Kingdom	O
,	O
Europe	O
and	O
Asia.	O
The	O
company	O
is	O
undertaking	O
exploration	O
at	O
CentroGold	O
,	O
Pedra	O
Branca	O
and	O
Pantera.	O
Corporate	O
Other	O
corporate	O
activities	O
include	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
group	O
office	O
(	O
which	O
includes	O
all	O
(	O
corporate	O
activities	O
)	O
corporate	O
expenses	O
that	O
cannot	O
be	O
directly	O
attributed	O
to	O
the	O
operation	O
of	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
operating	O
segments	O
)	O
,	O
other	O
investments	O
in	O
equity	O
securities	O
and	O
cash	O
balances.	O
Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
revenue	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
adopted	O
AASB	O
15	O
during	O
the	O
year.	O
The	O
revised	O
accounting	O
policy	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
revenue	O
is	O
set	O
out	O
below.	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
generates	O
sales	O
revenue	O
primarily	O
from	O
the	O
obligation	O
to	O
transfer	O
concentrate	O
to	O
the	O
buyer	O
and	O
in	O
some	O
cases	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
commercial	O
terms	O
of	O
the	O
contract	O
,	O
a	O
secondary	O
obligation	O
to	O
deliver	O
it	O
to	O
the	O
customer.	O
Revenue	O
is	O
allocated	O
between	O
the	O
performance	O
obligations	O
and	O
recognised	O
as	O
each	O
performance	O
obligation	O
is	O
met	O
,	O
which	O
for	O
the	O
primary	O
obligation	O
occurs	O
when	O
the	O
concentrate	O
is	O
delivered	O
to	O
a	O
vessel	O
or	O
location	O
and	O
for	O
the	O
secondary	O
obligation	O
,	O
if	O
applicable	O
,	O
when	O
the	O
concentrate	O
is	O
delivered	O
to	O
the	O
customer	O
’	O
s	O
location.	O
Revenue	O
arising	O
from	O
the	O
secondary	O
obligation	O
is	O
immaterial	O
to	O
the	O
Group	O
and	O
aggregated	O
with	O
the	O
primary	O
obligation	O
for	O
disclosure	O
purposes.	O
The	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
sale	O
of	O
concentrate	O
incurs	O
customary	O
treatment	O
and	O
refining	O
charges	O
and	O
other	O
commercial	O
costs	O
consistent	O
with	O
industry	O
practice.	O
These	O
items	O
are	O
in	O
essence	O
a	O
deduction	O
from	O
the	O
value	O
of	O
metal	O
contained	O
within	O
the	O
concentrate.	O
These	O
items	O
are	O
variable	O
in	O
nature	O
and	O
are	O
accounted	O
for	O
as	O
a	O
deduction	O
to	O
revenue	O
when	O
they	O
are	O
recognised.	O
As	O
is	O
industry	O
practice	O
,	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
typically	O
makes	O
sales	O
whereby	O
the	O
final	O
sales	O
price	O
for	O
the	O
primary	O
performance	O
obligation	O
is	O
determined	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
market	O
price	O
prevailing	O
at	O
a	O
date	O
in	O
the	O
future.	O
Revenue	O
for	O
the	O
primary	O
performance	O
obligation	O
is	O
measured	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
consideration	O
specified	O
in	O
a	O
contract	O
with	O
the	O
customer	O
at	O
the	O
time	O
of	O
settling	O
the	O
performance	O
obligation	O
and	O
is	O
determined	O
by	O
reference	O
to	O
forward	O
market	O
prices.	O
Provisional	O
pricing	O
adjustments	O
,	O
which	O
occur	O
between	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
at	O
the	O
time	O
of	O
settling	O
the	O
primary	O
performance	O
obligation	O
and	O
the	O
final	O
price	O
,	O
are	O
also	O
recorded	O
within	O
revenue.	O
Gains	O
and	O
losses	O
on	O
hedge	O
instruments	O
related	O
to	O
sales	O
contracts	O
are	O
also	O
recorded	O
in	O
revenue	O
and	O
generally	O
offset	O
the	O
movement	O
as	O
a	O
result	O
of	O
provisional	O
pricing	O
adjustments.	O

T	O
3.	O
Income	O
tax	O
Income	O
tax	O
expense	O
comprises	O
current	O
and	O
deferred	O
tax	O
of	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity.	O
Current	O
and	O
deferred	O
tax	O
expenses	O
are	O
recognised	O
in	O
other	O
comprehensive	O
income	O
or	O
directly	O
in	O
equity	O
as	O
is	O
appropriate.	O
RECOvERABILITY	O
OF	O
DEFERRED	O
TAX	O
ASSETS	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
is	O
subject	O
to	O
income	O
taxes	O
of	O
Australia	O
and	O
jurisdictions	O
where	O
it	O
has	O
foreign	O
operations.	O
Significant	O
judgement	O
is	O
required	O
in	O
the	O
application	O
of	O
income	O
tax	O
legislation	O
to	O
determine	O
the	O
provision	O
for	O
income	O
taxes.	O
There	O
are	O
many	O
transactions	O
and	O
calculations	O
undertaken	O
during	O
the	O
ordinary	O
course	O
of	O
business	O
for	O
which	O
the	O
ultimate	O
tax	O
determination	O
is	O
uncertain	O
,	O
and	O
for	O
which	O
provisions	O
are	O
based	O
on	O
estimated	O
amounts.	O
Where	O
the	O
final	O
tax	O
outcome	O
of	O
these	O
matters	O
is	O
different	O
from	O
the	O
amounts	O
that	O
were	O
initially	O
recorded	O
,	O
such	O
differences	O
will	O
impact	O
the	O
current	O
and	O
deferred	O
tax	O
provision	O
in	O
the	O
period	O
in	O
which	O
the	O
determination	O
is	O
made.	O
Assumptions	O
about	O
the	O
generation	O
of	O
future	O
taxable	O
profits	O
influence	O
the	O
ability	O
of	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
to	O
recognise	O
(	O
or	O
continue	O
to	O
recognise	O
)	O
deferred	O
tax	O
assets.	O
Taxable	O
profit	O
estimates	O
are	O
based	O
on	O
estimated	O
future	O
production	O
and	O
sales	O
volumes	O
,	O
commodity	O
prices	O
,	O
foreign	O
exchange	O
rates	O
,	O
operating	O
costs	O
,	O
restoration	O
costs	O
and	O
capital	O
expenditure.	O
A	O
change	O
in	O
these	O
assumptions	O
may	O
impact	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
balance	O
sheet	O
in	O
future	O
periods.	O
Group	O
taxation	O
The	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O

Recognition	O

of	O

Current	O
tax	O
The	O
tax	O
currently	O
payable	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
taxable	O
profit	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
,	O
using	O
rates	O
enacted	O
or	O
substantively	O
enacted	O
at	O
the	O
reporting	O
date	O
,	O
and	O
any	O
adjustments	O
to	O
tax	O
payable	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
previous	O
years.	O
Deferred	O
tax	O
Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
are	O
determined	O
using	O
the	O
balance	O
sheet	O
method	O
which	O
calculates	O
temporary	O
differences	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
in	O
the	O
balance	O
sheet	O
and	O
their	O
associated	O
tax	O
bases.	O
Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
are	O
not	O
recognised	O
for	O
temporary	O
differences	O
arising	O
from	O
investments	O
in	O
subsidiaries	O
where	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
is	O
able	O
to	O
control	O
the	O
reversal	O
of	O
the	O
temporary	O
differences	O
,	O
and	O
it	O
is	O
probable	O
that	O
they	O
will	O
not	O
reverse	O
in	O
the	O
foreseeable	O
future.	O
Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
are	O
recognised	O
to	O
the	O
extent	O
that	O
it	O
is	O
probable	O
that	O
future	O
taxable	O
income	O
will	O
be	O
available	O
to	O
utilise	O
them.	O

AND	O

The	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
is	O
reviewed	O
at	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
each	O
reporting	O
date	O
and	O
adjusted	O
based	O
on	O
estimates	O
of	O
future	O
taxable	O
income	O
and/or	O
capital	O
gains	O
against	O
which	O
the	O
deferred	O
tax	O
asset	O
could	O
be	O
utilised.	O
Deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
are	O
measured	O
at	O
the	O
tax	O
rates	O
applicable	O
to	O
each	O
jurisdiction	O
which	O
are	O
expected	O
to	O
apply	O
in	O
the	O
period	O
when	O
the	O
assets	O
are	O
realised	O
or	O
liabilities	O
discharged.	O
They	O
are	O
offset	O
where	O
they	O
relate	O
to	O
the	O
same	O
tax	O
authority	O
and	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
legally-enforceable	O
right	O
to	O
offset.	O

Inventories	O
NET	O
REALISABLE	O
vALUE	O
OF	O
INvENTORIES	O
Inventories	O
are	O
recognised	O
at	O
the	O
lower	O
of	O
cost	O
and	O
net	O
realisable	O
value	O
(	O
NRV	O
)	O
.	O

NRV	O
of	O
ore	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
estimated	O
amount	O
expected	O
to	O
be	O
received	O
when	O
the	O
ore	O
is	O
processed	O
and	O
sold	O
,	O
less	O
incremental	O
costs	O
to	O
convert	O
the	O
ore	O
to	O
concentrate	O
and	O
selling	O
costs.	O
The	O
computation	O
of	O
NRV	O
for	O
stockpiles	O
involves	O
significant	O
judgements	O
and	O
estimates	O
in	O
relation	O
to	O
future	O
ore	O
blend	O
rates	O
,	O
timing	O
of	O
processing	O
,	O
processing	O
costs	O
,	O
commodity	O
prices	O
,	O
foreign	O
exchange	O
rates	O
,	O
discount	O
rates	O
and	O
the	O
ultimate	O
timing	O
of	O
sale	O
of	O
concentrates	O
produced.	O
A	O
change	O
in	O
any	O
of	O
these	O
critical	O
assumptions	O
will	O
alter	O
the	O
estimated	O
NRV	O
and	O
may	O
therefore	O
impact	O
the	O
carrying	O
value	O
of	O
inventories.	O

An	O

of	O
the	O
NRV	O
of	O

gold	O
ore	O
stockpiles	O

:	O

.	O

The	O
increase	O
is	O
a	O
reversal	O
of	O
a	O
previous	O
impairment.	O
Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
inventories	O
Inventory	O
is	O
valued	O
at	O
the	O
lower	O
of	O
cost	O
incurred	O
to	O
bring	O
product	O
to	O
its	O
present	O
location	O
and	O
condition	O
,	O
and	O
NRV.	O
Costs	O
are	O
assigned	O
to	O
individual	O
items	O
of	O
inventory	O
on	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
weighted	O
average	O
costs.	O
Costs	O
comprise	O
direct	O
materials	O
and	O
labour	O
and	O
a	O
proportion	O
of	O
overhead	O
expenditure	O
directly	O
related	O
to	O
the	O
production	O
of	O
inventories.	O
Expenditure	O
directly	O
related	O
to	O
the	O
production	O
of	O
inventories	O
includes	O
processing	O
costs	O
;	O
transportation	O
costs	O
to	O
the	O
point	O
of	O
sale	O
;	O
and	O
depreciation	O
of	O
plant	O
,	O
equipment	O
,	O
mining	O
property	O
and	O
development	O
assets	O
,	O
the	O
latter	O
of	O
which	O
includes	O
deferred	O
stripping	O
assets	O
and	O
mine	O
rehabilitation	O
costs	O
incurred	O
in	O
the	O
mining	O
process.	O
NRV	O
is	O
calculated	O
by	O
estimating	O
the	O
value	O
that	O
is	O
expected	O
to	O
be	O
realised	O
upon	O
sale	O
of	O
concentrate	O
after	O
deducting	O
the	O
estimated	O
costs	O
of	O
processing	O
and	O
selling	O
costs.	O
This	O
estimation	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
assumptions	O
of	O
future	O
prices	O
and	O
costs	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
expected	O
future	O
ore	O
blend	O
rates	O
and	O
processing	O
timing.	O
Inventories	O
expected	O
to	O
be	O
processed	O
or	O
sold	O
within	O
12	O
months	O
after	O
the	O
balance	O
date	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
current	O
assets	O
and	O
all	O
other	O
inventories	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
non-current.	O

’	O
s	O

flow	O

to	O
profit	O
after	O
tax	O
is	O
as	O
follows.	O
2018	O
2017	O
$m	O
$m	O
Profit	O
after	O
tax	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
222.4	O
231.1	O
Adjustments	O
for	O
:	O
Depreciation	O
148.3	O
323.5	O
Lease	O
amortisation	O
1.8	O
7.9	O
Foreign	O
exchange	O
loss	O
on	O
cash	O
balances	O
(	O
3.4	O
)	O
5.2	O
Share	O
based	O
payments	O
4.7	O
5.3	O
Other	O
items	O
3.9	O
5.4	O
Change	O
in	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O

of	O

and	O

stated	O
at	O
cost	O
less	O
accumulated	O

and	O

losses.	O
Cost	O

that	O
is	O
directly	O
attributable	O
to	O
the	O
acquisition	O
of	O
the	O
items	O
and	O
costs	O
incurred	O
in	O
bringing	O
assets	O
into	O
use.	O
Expenditure	O
associated	O
with	O
mining	O
which	O
relates	O
to	O
developing	O
access	O
to	O
new	O
sections	O
of	O
an	O
ore	O
body	O
is	O
capitalised	O
as	O
a	O
mine	O
development	O
asset	O
and	O
depreciated	O
on	O
a	O
units	O
of	O
production	O
basis	O
as	O
ore	O
is	O
extracted.	O
When	O

and	O
mine	O
development	O
occurs	O
concurrently	O
expenditure	O
is	O
allocated	O
between	O

cost	O
of	O
ore	O

(	O
inventory	O
)	O
and	O

of	O

or	O
material	O

of	O
Avanco.	O
Mineral	O
rights	O
comprise	O
identifiable	O
exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
assets	O
,	O
mineral	O
resources	O
and	O
ore	O
reserves	O
which	O
are	O
acquired	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
a	O
business	O
combination	O
and	O
are	O
recognised	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
at	O
date	O
of	O
acquisition.	O
Mine	O
property	O
and	O
development	O
assets	O
include	O
costs	O
transferred	O
from	O
exploration	O
and	O
evaluation	O
assets	O
once	O
technical	O
feasibility	O
and	O
commercial	O
viability	O
of	O
an	O
area	O
of	O
interest	O
are	O
demonstrable.	O
After	O
transfer	O
,	O
all	O
subsequent	O
expenditures	O
to	O
develop	O
the	O
mine	O
to	O
the	O
production	O
phase	O
which	O
are	O
considered	O
to	O
benefit	O
mining	O
operations	O
in	O
future	O
periods	O
are	O
capitalised.	O
The	O
proceeds	O
from	O
the	O
sale	O
of	O
any	O
concentrate	O
produced	O
from	O
ore	O
extracted	O
and	O
processed	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
development	O
of	O
the	O
asset	O
prior	O
to	O
being	O
deemed	O
ready	O
for	O
use	O
are	O
deducted	O
from	O
the	O
cost	O
of	O
the	O
asset	O
,	O
less	O
any	O
further	O
processing	O
and	O
selling	O
costs	O
incurred.	O
The	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
expected	O
cost	O
of	O
decommissioning	O
an	O
asset	O
after	O
its	O
use	O
is	O
included	O
in	O
the	O
cost	O
of	O
the	O
respective	O
asset	O
if	O
the	O
recognition	O
criteria	O
for	O
a	O
provision	O
are	O
met.	O
Property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
is	O
tested	O
for	O
impairment	O
when	O
there	O
is	O
an	O
indication	O
of	O
impairment.	O
For	O
the	O
purposes	O
of	O
assessing	O
impairment	O
,	O
assets	O
are	O
grouped	O
at	O
the	O
lowest	O
levels	O
for	O
which	O
there	O
are	O
separately	O
identifiable	O
cash	O
inflows.	O
An	O
impairment	O
loss	O
is	O
recognised	O
for	O
the	O
amount	O
by	O
which	O
the	O
asset	O
or	O
cash	O
generating	O
unit	O
(	O
CGU	O
)	O
carrying	O
amount	O
exceeds	O
its	O
recoverable	O
amount.	O
The	O
recoverable	O
amount	O
is	O
the	O
higher	O
of	O
an	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
fair	O
value	O
,	O
less	O
costs	O
to	O
dispose	O
and	O
its	O
value	O
in	O
use.	O
Assets	O
that	O
have	O
been	O
impaired	O
are	O
reviewed	O
for	O
possible	O
reversal	O
of	O
impairment	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date.	O
Value	O
in	O
use	O
is	O
the	O
net	O
amount	O
expected	O
to	O
be	O
recovered	O
through	O
cash	O
flows	O
arising	O
from	O
continued	O
use	O
and	O
subsequent	O
disposal	O
of	O
an	O
asset	O
(	O
or	O
group	O
of	O
assets	O
)	O
.	O

In	O
assessing	O
value	O
in	O
use	O
,	O
estimated	O
future	O
cash	O
flows	O
are	O
discounted	O
to	O
their	O
present	O
value	O
using	O
a	O
pre-tax	O
discount	O
rate	O
that	O
reflects	O
current	O
market	O
assessments	O
of	O
the	O
time	O
value	O
of	O
money	O
and	O
risks	O
specific	O
to	O
the	O
asset.	O
The	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
fair	O
value	O
less	O
costs	O
to	O
dispose	O
is	O
the	O
amount	O
obtainable	O
from	O
the	O
sale	O
of	O
an	O
asset	O
or	O
cash-generating	O
unit	O
in	O
an	O
arm	O
’	O
s	O
length	O
transaction	O
between	O
knowledgeable	O
and	O
willing	O
parties	O
,	O
less	O
the	O
estimated	O
costs	O
of	O
disposal.	O
A	O
fair	O
value	O
measurement	O
of	O
a	O
non-financial	O
asset	O
takes	O
into	O
account	O
a	O
market	O
participant	O
’	O
s	O
ability	O
to	O
generate	O
economic	O
benefits	O
by	O
using	O
the	O
asset	O
in	O
its	O
highest	O
and	O
best	O
use	O
,	O
or	O
by	O
selling	O
it	O
to	O
another	O
market	O
participant	O
that	O
would	O
use	O
the	O
asset	O
in	O
its	O
highest	O
and	O
best	O
use.	O
RECOvERABILITY	O
OF	O
ASSETS	O
Cash	O

units	O
are	O
tested	O
for	O
impairment	O
when	O

is	O
an	O
indication	O
that	O
the	O
CGU	O
may	O
be	O
impaired.	O
Examples	O

the	O

’	O
s	O

assets	O

its	O
market	O
capitalisation	O
,	O

in	O

and	O
foreign	O
exchange	O
rates	O
,	O
or	O
a	O
decline	O
in	O
the	O
CGU	O
’	O
s	O
operating	O
performance.	O
The	O

Entity	O
undertook	O
a	O

Prominent	O
Hill	O
,	O
Carrapateena	O

Carajas	O
CGU	O

no	O

was	O

in	O
an	O
arm	O
’	O
s	O
length	O
transaction.	O
When	O

reviewed	O

CGU	O
’	O

valuation	O
in	O

periods	O
,	O

:	O
/	O
expected	O

of	O

In	O

mining	O
inventory	O
applicable	O
to	O
the	O
development	O
Depreciation	O
of	O
assets	O
commences	O
when	O
the	O
assets	O
are	O
ready	O
for	O
their	O
intended	O
use.	O
The	O
depreciation	O
of	O
mine	O
property	O
and	O
development	O
commences	O
when	O
the	O
mine	O
is	O
commissioned	O
or	O
deemed	O
ready	O
for	O
use.	O
The	O
residual	O
values	O
,	O
useful	O
lives	O
and	O
methods	O
of	O
depreciation	O
of	O
property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
are	O
reviewed	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
period	O
and	O
adjusted	O
prospectively	O
,	O
if	O
appropriate.	O
Where	O
depreciation	O
rates	O
are	O
changed	O
,	O
the	O
net	O
written	O
down	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
asset	O
is	O
depreciated	O
from	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
the	O
change	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
new	O
depreciation	O
rate	O
,	O
with	O
the	O
change	O
accounted	O
for	O
as	O
a	O
change	O
in	O
accounting	O
estimate.	O
MINERAL	O
RESOURCE	O
AND	O
ORE	O
RESERvE	O
ESTIMATES	O
The	O
estimated	O
quantities	O
of	O
mineral	O
resource	O
and	O
ore	O
reserve	O
estimates	O
are	O
based	O
upon	O
interpretations	O
of	O
geological	O
and	O
geophysical	O
models	O
and	O
require	O
assumptions	O
to	O
be	O
made	O
regarding	O
exchange	O
rates	O
,	O
commodity	O
prices	O
,	O
future	O
capital	O
requirements	O
and	O
future	O
operating	O
performance.	O
Changes	O
in	O
reported	O
mineral	O
resource	O
and	O
ore	O
reserve	O
estimates	O
can	O
impact	O
the	O
carrying	O
value	O
of	O
property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
,	O
including	O
deferred	O
mining	O
expenditure	O
;	O
intangible	O
assets	O
;	O
capitalised	O
exploration	O
;	O
provisions	O
for	O
mine	O
rehabilitation	O
,	O
restoration	O
and	O
dismantling	O
obligations	O
;	O
and	O
recognition	O
of	O
deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
depreciation	O
charged	O
to	O
the	O
income	O
statement.	O
Changes	O
in	O
the	O
carrying	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
assets	O
may	O
arise	O
principally	O
through	O
changes	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
that	O
can	O
be	O
economically	O
generated	O
from	O
each	O
project.	O
Changes	O
in	O
depreciation	O
expense	O
may	O
arise	O
through	O
a	O
change	O
in	O
the	O
useful	O
life	O
over	O
which	O
property	O
,	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
is	O
depreciated.	O
8.	O
Provisions	O
MINE	O
REHABILITATION	O
,	O
RESTORATION	O
&	O
DISMANTLING	O
OBLIGATIONS	O
The	O
provision	O
for	O
mine	O
rehabilitation	O
includes	O
future	O
cost	O
estimates	O
associated	O
with	O
reclamation	O
,	O
plant	O
closures	O
,	O
waste	O
site	O
closures	O
,	O
monitoring	O
,	O
demobilisation	O
of	O
equipment	O
,	O
decontamination	O
,	O
water	O
purification	O
and	O
permanent	O
storage	O
of	O
historical	O
residues.	O
Uncertainty	O
exists	O
as	O
to	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
rehabilitation	O
obligations	O
which	O
will	O
be	O
incurred	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
impact	O
of	O
environmental	O
legislation	O
changes	O
and	O
many	O
other	O
factors	O
,	O
including	O
future	O
changes	O
in	O
technology	O
,	O
price	O
increases	O
and	O
changes	O
in	O
interest	O
rates.	O
The	O
calculation	O
of	O
these	O
provision	O
estimates	O
requires	O
assumptions	O
to	O
be	O
made	O
as	O
to	O
:	O
the	O
application	O
of	O
environmental	O
legislation	O
,	O
plant	O
closure	O
dates	O
,	O
available	O
technologies	O
,	O
engineering	O
cost	O
estimates	O
and	O
discount	O
rates.	O
A	O
change	O
in	O
any	O
of	O
the	O
assumptions	O
used	O
may	O
have	O
a	O
material	O
impact	O
on	O
the	O
carrying	O
value	O
of	O
mine	O
rehabilitation	O
,	O
restoration	O
and	O
dismantling	O
provisions.	O
Recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
of	O
provisions	O
Provisions	O
are	O
measured	O
at	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
best	O
estimate	O
of	O
the	O
expenditure	O
required	O
to	O
settle	O
the	O
present	O
obligation	O
at	O
balance	O
sheet	O
date.	O
The	O
discount	O
rate	O
used	O
to	O
determine	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
reflects	O
current	O
market	O
assessments	O
of	O
the	O
time	O
value	O
of	O
money	O
and	O
the	O
risks	O
specific	O
to	O
the	O
liability.	O
The	O
increase	O
in	O
provisions	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
passage	O
of	O
time	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement	O
as	O
financing	O
expenses.	O
114	O
ANNUAL	O
AND	O
SUSTAINABILITY	O
REPORT	O
2018F	O
IN	O
A	O
N	O
C	O
IA	O
L	O
R	O
E	O
P	O
O	O
R	O
T	O
Provisions	O
are	O
made	O
for	O
the	O
estimated	O
cost	O
of	O
rehabilitation	O
,	O
decommissioning	O
and	O
restoration	O
of	O
areas	O
disturbed	O
during	O
mining	O
and	O
exploration	O
operations	O
up	O
to	O
the	O
reporting	O
date	O
for	O
areas	O
not	O
yet	O
rehabilitated.	O
Provisions	O
for	O
mine	O
rehabilitation	O
are	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
current	O
estimated	O
cost	O
to	O
rehabilitate	O
such	O
areas	O
,	O
discounted	O
to	O
their	O
present	O
value	O
based	O
on	O
expected	O
future	O
cash	O
flows.	O
The	O
estimated	O
costs	O
include	O
the	O
current	O
cost	O
of	O
rehabilitation	O
necessary	O
to	O
meet	O
legislative	O
requirements.	O
Changes	O
in	O
estimates	O
are	O
dealt	O
with	O
on	O
a	O
prospective	O
basis	O
as	O
they	O
arise.	O
The	O
provision	O
is	O
recognised	O
as	O
a	O
liability	O
,	O
separated	O
into	O
current	O
(	O
estimated	O
costs	O
arising	O
within	O
12	O
months	O
)	O
and	O
non-current	O
components	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
expected	O
timing	O
of	O
these	O
cash	O
flows.	O
Provision	O
for	O
demobilisation	O
relates	O
to	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
obligation	O
to	O
reimburse	O
contractors	O
for	O
the	O
cost	O
of	O
removing	O
equipment	O
from	O
a	O
mine	O
site.	O

of	O
the	O
equipment	O
while	O
in	O
use	O
at	O
OZ	O

Ordinary	O

entitle	O

to	O

the	O

Company	O

a	O

hands	O

shares	O

at	O

one	O

per	O
share.	O

and	O

of	O

are	O

as	O
equity.	O

costs	O

of	O

to	O
the	O
instruments.	O

of	O
the	O

to	O

at	O

about	O

of	O

are	O

and	O

at	O
each	O

Function	O
(	O

of	O

Consolidated	O
Entity.	O
Group	O

and	O

financial	O
risks	O
in	O
close	O

OZ	O

operating	O
units.	O
The	O
Board	O

for	O
overall	O
risk	O
management	O
as	O

as	O

and	O

about	O
the	O

’	O

and	O

cost.	O
Financial	O
assets	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
are	O
recognised	O
initially	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
plus	O
any	O
directly	O
attributable	O
transaction	O
costs.	O
Trade	O
receivables	O
,	O
including	O
those	O
containing	O
an	O
embedded	O
derivative	O
,	O
are	O
carried	O
at	O
fair	O
value.	O
Concentrate	O
sales	O
receivables	O
are	O
recognised	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
recognition	O
and	O
measurement	O
criteria	O
disclosed	O
in	O
Note	O
one.	O
Provisional	O
payments	O
in	O
relation	O
to	O
trade	O
receivables	O
are	O
usually	O
due	O
within	O
30	O
days	O
from	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
invoice	O
issue	O
,	O
with	O
final	O
settlement	O

due	O
within	O
60	O
days.	O

are	O
recognised	O
initially	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
and	O
subsequently	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
using	O
the	O
effective	O
interest	O
method.	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
de-recognises	O
a	O
financial	O
asset	O
or	O
a	O
part	O
of	O
it	O
when	O
,	O
and	O
only	O
when	O
,	O
the	O
contractual	O
rights	O
to	O
the	O
cash	O
flows	O
from	O
the	O
financial	O
asset	O
expire	O
or	O

financial	O
asset	O
is	O
transferred	O
to	O
another	O
party	O
without	O
retaining	O
control	O
or	O
substantially	O
all	O
risks	O
and	O
rewards	O
of	O
the	O
asset.	O
On	O
de-recognition	O
of	O
a	O
financial	O
asset	O
,	O
the	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
(	O
measured	O
at	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
de-recognition	O
)	O
and	O
the	O
consideration	O
received	O
(	O
including	O
any	O
new	O
asset	O
obtained	O
less	O
any	O
new	O
liability	O
assumed	O
)	O
and	O
any	O
cumulative	O
gain	O
or	O
loss	O
that	O
had	O
been	O
recognised	O
in	O
equity	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement.	O
A	O
financial	O
asset	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
is	O
assessed	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date	O
as	O
to	O
whether	O
there	O
is	O
any	O
objective	O
evidence	O
of	O
impairment	O
as	O
a	O
result	O
of	O
one	O
or	O
more	O
events	O
having	O
an	O
impact	O
on	O
the	O
estimated	O
future	O
cash	O
flows	O
of	O
the	O
asset.	O
119An	O
impairment	O
loss	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
financial	O
assets	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement	O
and	O
is	O
measured	O
as	O
the	O
difference	O
between	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
carrying	O
amount	O
and	O
the	O
present	O
value	O
of	O
estimated	O
future	O
cash	O
flows	O
discounted	O
at	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
original	O
effective	O
interest	O
rate.	O
The	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
asset	O
is	O
reduced	O
through	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
an	O
allowance	O
account.	O
In	O
the	O
event	O
that	O
an	O
impairment	O
loss	O
is	O
reversed	O
,	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
carrying	O
amount	O
cannot	O
exceed	O
what	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O

have	O
been	O

the	O
impairment	O
not	O
been	O
recognised.	O
The	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O

is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement.	O
Non-derivative	O
financial	O
liabilities	O
All	O
financial	O
liabilities	O
are	O

initially	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
and	O
net	O
of	O

attributable	O
transaction	O
costs.	O
Trade	O
and	O
other	O
payables	O
represent	O
liabilities	O
for	O
goods	O
and	O
services	O
provided	O
to	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
prior	O
to	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
which	O
are	O
unpaid.	O
The	O
amounts	O
are	O
non-interest-bearing	O
,	O
unsecured	O
and	O
are	O
usually	O
paid	O
within	O
30	O
days	O
of	O
recognition.	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O

financial	O
liabilities	O
when	O
its	O
obligations	O
are	O
discharged	O
,	O
cancelled	O
or	O
expire.	O

difference	O
between	O

of	O

de-recognised	O
and	O
the	O
consideration	O
paid	O
and	O
payable	O
is	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement	O

financial	O
instruments	O

and	O
measurement	O
Derivative	O

at	O

on	O

into	O
and	O
are	O

remeasured	O
to	O
their	O

value	O
at	O
each	O

date.	O
Changes	O
in	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
of	O
any	O
derivative	O
instrument	O
are	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
income	O
statement	O
or	O
other	O
comprehensive	O
income	O
,	O
based	O
the	O
designation	O
and	O
effectiveness	O
of	O
the	O
hedge	O
instrument.	O

designation	O
of	O

hedge	O
and	O

between	O

and	O
the	O

item	O
is	O

at	O

of	O
the	O

in	O

of	O

,	O

other	O

its	O
contractual	O
obligations	O
resulting	O
in	O
financial	O
loss	O
to	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity.	O
Counterparty	O
credit	O
risk	O
arises	O
through	O
sales	O
of	O
metal	O
in	O
concentrate	O
on	O
normal	O
terms	O
of	O
trade	O
,	O
cash	O
deposits	O
and	O
derivative	O
financial	O
instruments.	O
At	O
the	O
reporting	O
date	O
,	O

amount	O
of	O
financial	O
assets	O
in	O
the	O
balance	O
sheet	O
represents	O
the	O
maximum	O
credit	O
exposure	O
on	O
cash	O
and	O
cash	O
equivalents	O
,	O
trade	O
receivables	O
,	O
other	O
receivables	O
and	O
derivative	O
assets.	O
The	O
credit	O
risk	O
on	O
cash	O
and	O
cash	O
equivalents	O
is	O
managed	O
by	O
restricting	O
material	O
financial	O
transactions	O
to	O
banks	O
which	O
are	O
assigned	O
an	O
S&P	O
equivalent	O
of	O
A-1	O
short	O
term	O
credit	O
ratings	O
by	O

agencies	O

Management	O
Policy.	O
Credit	O
risk	O
in	O
trade	O
receivables	O
is	O

by	O
undertaking	O

risk	O

and	O
reviewing	O
credit	O
limits	O
of	O
customers.	O
As	O
there	O
are	O
a	O
relatively	O
small	O
number	O
of	O
transactions	O
,	O
they	O
are	O

monitored	O
to	O
ensure	O
risk	O
of	O
default	O
is	O
kept	O
to	O
an	O
acceptable	O
level.	O
Sales	O
contracts	O
generally	O

of	O
at	O
least	O
90	O
per	O
cent	O
of	O
the	O
estimated	O
value	O
of	O
each	O

vessel	O

or	O
upon	O
the	O
vessel	O
arriving	O
at	O
the	O
discharge	O
port.	O

of	O

with	O

13.	O
Contingencies	O
CONTINGENCIES	O
By	O
their	O
nature	O
,	O
contingencies	O
will	O
only	O
be	O
resolved	O
when	O
one	O
or	O
more	O
uncertain	O
future	O
events	O
occur	O
or	O
fail	O
to	O
occur.	O
Determination	O
of	O
contingent	O
liabilities	O
disclosed	O
in	O
the	O
financial	O
statements	O
requires	O
the	O
exercise	O
of	O
significant	O
judgement	O
regarding	O
the	O
outcome	O
of	O
future	O
events.	O
The	O
financial	O
results	O
of	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
in	O
future	O
periods	O
may	O
be	O
impacted	O
unfavourably	O
in	O
the	O
event	O
of	O
an	O
unfavourable	O
outcome	O
of	O
a	O
number	O
of	O
matters	O
outlined	O
in	O
this	O
note.	O
Bank	O
guarantees	O
OZ	O
Minerals	O
Group	O
Treasury	O
Pty	O
Ltd	O
has	O
provided	O
certain	O
bank	O

to	O
third	O
parties	O
,	O

with	O
the	O
terms	O
of	O

and	O

in	O
respect	O
of	O
which	O

relevant	O
entity	O
is	O

to	O

the	O
bank	O
if	O

is	O
called	O
upon.	O
At	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
year	O
,	O
no	O
claims	O
have	O
been	O
made	O
under	O
any	O
of	O
these	O
guarantees.	O

amount	O
of	O

of	O
these	O

may	O
vary	O
from	O
time	O
to	O
time	O

upon	O
the	O
requirements	O
of	O
the	O
recipient.	O

amounted	O
to	O
$209.1	O
million	O
as	O
at	O
31	O
December	O
2018	O
(	O
31	O
December	O
2017	O
:	O
$52.9	O
million	O
)	O
and	O
are	O
backed	O
by	O
deposits.	O

,	O

required	O

arise.	O

ANNUAL	O
AND	O
SUSTAINABILITY	O
REPORT	O
2018F	O
IN	O
A	O
N	O
C	O
IA	O
L	O
R	O
E	O
P	O
O	O
R	O
T	O
Basis	O
of	O
consolidation	O
Investments	O
in	O
subsidiaries	O
Subsidiaries	O
are	O
those	O
entities	O
over	O
which	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
is	O
capable	O
of	O
exerting	O
control.	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
controls	O
an	O
entity	O
when	O
it	O
is	O
exposed	O
to	O
,	O
or	O
has	O
rights	O
to	O
,	O
variable	O
returns	O
from	O
its	O
involvement	O
with	O
the	O
entity	O
and	O
has	O
the	O
ability	O
to	O
affect	O
those	O
returns	O
through	O
its	O
power	O
over	O
the	O
entity.	O
Where	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
holds	O
less	O
than	O
a	O
majority	O
of	O
the	O
voting	O
rights	O
,	O
other	O
relevant	O
factors	O
are	O
considered	O
in	O
assessing	O
whether	O
power	O
over	O
the	O
entity	O
exists.	O
Factors	O
considered	O
include	O
rights	O
arising	O
from	O
other	O
contractual	O
arrangements	O
,	O
any	O
contractual	O
arrangements	O
with	O
other	O
vote	O
holders	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
voting	O
and	O
potential	O
voting	O
rights.	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
reassesses	O
whether	O
it	O
controls	O
an	O
entity	O
if	O
circumstances	O
indicate	O
that	O
there	O
has	O
been	O
a	O
change	O
in	O
one	O
of	O
the	O
factors	O
which	O
indicate	O
control.	O
Subsidiaries	O
are	O
consolidated	O
from	O
the	O
date	O
on	O
which	O
control	O
is	O
assessed	O
to	O
exist	O
until	O
the	O
date	O
that	O
control	O
ceases.	O
The	O
purchase	O
method	O
of	O
accounting	O
is	O
used	O
to	O
account	O
for	O
the	O
acquisition	O
of	O
subsidiaries	O
by	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity.	O
Intercompany	O
transactions	O
,	O
balances	O
and	O
unrealised	O
gains	O
and	O
losses	O
on	O
transactions	O
between	O
companies	O
controlled	O
by	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
are	O
eliminated	O
on	O
consolidation.	O
During	O
the	O
year	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
incorporated	O

New	O

standards	O
(	O
i	O
)	O
Changes	O
in	O

policies	O
and	O
mandatory	O
standards	O
adopted	O
during	O
the	O
year	O
The	O
accounting	O
policies	O
applied	O
by	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
in	O
these	O
Consolidated	O
Financial	O
Statements	O
are	O
consistent	O
with	O
those	O
applied	O
by	O
the	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
in	O
its	O
Annual	O
Report	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
ended	O
31	O
December	O
2017	O
except	O
for	O
the	O
application	O
for	O
the	O
AASB	O
15	O
as	O
described	O
below.	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
has	O
adopted	O
all	O
of	O
the	O
new	O
,	O
revised	O
or	O
amending	O
standards	O
that	O
are	O
mandatory.	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
has	O
for	O
the	O
first	O
time	O
applied	O
AASB	O
15	O
Revenue	O
from	O
Contracts	O
with	O
Customers	O
with	O
effect	O
from	O
1	O
January	O
2018.	O
AASB	O
15	O
Revenue	O
from	O
contracts	O
with	O
customers	O
AASB	O
15	O
changes	O
the	O
timing	O
(	O
and	O
in	O
some	O
case	O
,	O
the	O
quantum	O
)	O
of	O
revenue	O
recognised	O
from	O
customers.	O
Under	O
the	O
previous	O
standard	O
revenue	O
for	O
domestic	O
sales	O
is	O
recognised	O
when	O
the	O
concentrates	O
are	O
delivered	O
to	O
the	O
customers	O
’	O
premises	O
,	O
which	O
is	O
the	O
point	O
when	O
the	O
customer	O
takes	O
over	O
the	O
risk	O
and	O
rewards	O
of	O
ownership	O
transfer.	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
assessment	O
indicates	O
that	O
under	O
AASB	O
15	O
,	O
revenue	O
is	O
continued	O
to	O
be	O
recognised	O
on	O
the	O
same	O
basis	O
when	O
the	O
customer	O
obtains	O
control	O
of	O
the	O
concentrates.	O
Revenue	O
for	O
export	O
sales	O
was	O
recognised	O
when	O
shipments	O
of	O
concentrates	O
were	O
loaded	O
on	O
to	O
the	O
vessel	O
as	O
the	O
risk	O
and	O
reward	O
of	O
ownership	O
was	O
transferred	O
to	O
the	O
customer	O
at	O
that	O
point.	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
’	O
s	O
assessment	O
under	O
AASB	O
15	O
indicates	O
that	O
the	O
export	O
contracts	O
are	O
made	O
up	O
of	O
two	O
performance	O
obligations.	O
The	O
first	O
obligation	O
is	O
to	O
deliver	O
the	O
concentrates	O
to	O
the	O
port	O
of	O
shipment	O
and	O
the	O
second	O
obligation	O
is	O
to	O
organise	O
shipping	O
of	O
the	O
concentrate	O
,	O
which	O
will	O
be	O
satisfied	O
when	O
concentrates	O
are	O
delivered	O
to	O
the	O
destination	O
port.	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
assessed	O
that	O
revenue	O
relating	O
to	O
the	O
first	O
obligation	O
of	O
delivery	O
of	O
the	O
concentrates	O
to	O
the	O
port	O
of	O
shipping	O
will	O
be	O
recognised	O
at	O
that	O
point	O
and	O
revenue	O
relating	O
to	O
the	O
shipping	O
obligation	O
will	O
be	O
recognised	O
in	O
future	O
periods	O
upon	O

impact	O

At	O
the	O
date	O
of	O

the	O

,	O
the	O

AASB	O
Standards	O
had	O
been	O
issued	O
but	O
were	O
not	O
yet	O
effective.	O
AASB	O
16	O
Leases	O
AASB	O
16	O
Leases	O
eliminates	O
the	O
distinction	O
between	O
operating	O
and	O
finance	O
leases	O
and	O
brings	O
all	O
leases	O
(	O
other	O
than	O
short	O
term	O
and	O
low	O
value	O
leases	O
)	O
onto	O
the	O
balance	O
sheet.	O
A	O
lessee	O
recognises	O
a	O
right-of-use	O
asset	O
representing	O
its	O
right	O
to	O
use	O
the	O
underlying	O
asset	O
and	O
a	O
lease	O
liability	O
representing	O
its	O
obligation	O
to	O
make	O
lease	O
payments.	O
The	O
standard	O
is	O
applicable	O
to	O
annual	O
reporting	O
periods	O
beginning	O
on	O
or	O
after	O
1	O
January	O
2019.	O
The	O
AASB	O
16	O
will	O
result	O
in	O
higher	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
on	O
the	O
balance	O
sheet	O
and	O

of	O

AASB	O
16	O
will	O
be	O
recognised	O
as	O
an	O
adjustment	O
to	O
the	O
opening	O
balance	O
of	O
retained	O
earnings	O
at	O
1	O
January	O
2019	O
with	O
no	O
restatement	O
of	O
comparative	O
information.	O
The	O
Consolidated	O
Entity	O
will	O
recognise	O
right-of-use	O
assets	O
and	O
lease	O
liabilities	O
for	O
the	O
arrangements	O

as	O

will	O

1	O

2019.	O

OZ	O

to	O

of	O

16	O

for	O

assets	O
and	O

on	O

Glossary	O
Acid	O
rock	O

Hectare	O
(	O

)	O
Site	O
culture	O

strategy	O
When	O

are	O

to	O

and	O
A	O

area	O

to	O
A	O
Prominent	O
Hill	O
initiative	O
that	O

rain	O
,	O
a	O
reaction	O
can	O

the	O

10	O

Usually	O
used	O
employee	O
and	O

in	O
the	O
rock	O
which	O
results	O

a	O

in	O
the	O
to	O

of	O

,	O
oxidation	O
IUCN	O
Red	O

can	O

the	O

for	O

)	O

(	O

One	O

)	O
Copper	O
concentrate	O

is	O
the	O

recordable	O

)	O
injuries	O

The	O
Prominent	O
Hill	O
operation	O
produces	O
A	O

a	O
work-related	O
injury	O
or	O
Recordable	O
injuries	O
include	O
those	O
that	O
copper	O
concentrate.	O
This	O
is	O
a	O

illness	O

in	O
an	O
absence	O
from	O
rostered	O

of	O
LTIs	O
per	O

soils	O

barren	O

copper	O
in	O
Megalitre	O
(	O
ML	O
)	O
uneconomic	O
mineralised	O
rock	O
that	O
its	O
metal	O
form.	O
One	O

to	O
one	O

litres.	O
surrounds	O
a	O

orebody	O

of	O

Reserves	O
,	O

and	O
zones	O
of	O

may	O
also	O
be	O
deemed	O
to	O
be	O
forward	O
looking	O
statements	O
in	O
that	O

contain	O

that	O

to	O

thus	O
far.	O
Exploration	O
targets	O
are	O
conceptual	O
in	O
nature	O
and	O
are	O
formed	O
from	O
projection	O
of	O
the	O
known	O
resource	O
dimensions	O
along	O
strike.	O
The	O
quantity	O
and	O
grade	O
of	O
an	O
exploration	O
target	O
is	O
insufficient	O
to	O
define	O
a	O
Mineral	O
Resource.	O
Forward	O
looking	O
statements	O
are	O
not	O
statements	O
of	O
historical	O
fact	O
,	O
they	O
are	O
based	O
on	O
reasonable	O
projections	O
and	O
calculations	O
,	O
the	O
ultimate	O
results	O
or	O
outcomes	O
of	O
which	O
may	O
differ	O
materially	O
from	O
those	O
described	O
or	O
incorporated	O
in	O
the	O
forward-looking	O
statements.	O

or	O

to	O

or	O

Acknowledgment	O

of	O
exploration	O
The	O
Geological	O
Survey	O
of	O
Botswana	O
undertook	O
a	O

of	O
soil	O
geochemical	O
by	O
other	O
parties.	O
sampling	O
in	O
1982.	O

a	O

this	O
program	O
,	O

was	O

to	O

2003	O
and	O
has	O

then.	O
Geology	O
Deposit	O
type	O
,	O
geological	O
setting	O
and	O
style	O
of	O
The	O
Kihabe-Nxuu	O
Project	O
lies	O
in	O
the	O
NW	O
part	O
of	O
Botswana	O
at	O
the	O
southern	O
margin	O
mineralisation.	O
of	O
the	O
Congo	O
craton	O
The	O
Gossan	O
Anomaly	O
is	O
centred	O
on	O
an	O
exposed	O
gossan	O
within	O
the	O
project.	O
To	O
the	O
north	O
of	O
the	O
project	O
are	O
granitoids	O
,	O
ironstones	O
,	O
quartzites	O
and	O
mica	O
schists	O
of	O
the	O
Tsodilo	O
Hills	O
Group	O
covered	O
by	O
extensive	O
recent	O
Cainozoic	O
sediments	O
of	O
the	O
Kalahari	O
Group.	O
Below	O
the	O
extensive	O
Kalahari	O
sediments	O
are	O
siliciclastic	O
sediments	O
and	O
igneous	O
rocks	O
of	O
the	O
Karoo	O
Supergroup	O
in	O
fault	O
bounded	O
blocks.	O
The	O
Nxuu	O
deposit	O
mineralization	O
occurs	O
in	O
the	O
totally	O
oxidize	O
quartz	O
wacke	O
situated	O
within	O
a	O

gold	O
projects	O
concentrated	O
in	O
two	O
key	O
areas	O
:	O
West	O
Mali	O
(	O
Dandoko	O
,	O
Moussala	O
and	O
Socaf	O
)	O
and	O
South	O
Mali	O
(	O
Yanfolila	O
)	O
.	O

Both	O
groups	O
of	O
permits	O
are	O
located	O
over	O
highly	O
prospective	O
Proterozoic	O
Birimian	O
greenstone	O
belts	O
in	O
the	O
vicinity	O
of	O
multi-million-ounce	O
gold	O
mining	O
operations	O
and	O
recent	O
noteworthy	O
discoveries	O
(	O
Figure	O
1	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
Company	O
continued	O
to	O
make	O
significant	O
progress	O
in	O
advancing	O
its	O
projects	O
during	O
the	O
year.	O
Highlights	O
included	O
:	O
-	O

A	O
high-grade	O
gold	O
discovery	O
at	O
the	O
Diabarou	O
prospect	O
within	O
the	O
Dandoko	O

;	O

of	O

highly	O

Moussala	O
Project	O
permit	O

of	O

DANDOKO	O
PROJECT	O
–	O

West	O
Mali	O
(	O
100%	O
interest	O
)	O
The	O
Dandoko	O
permit	O
(	O
134km2	O
)	O
is	O
located	O
within	O
the	O
Kenieba	O
Inlier	O
of	O
western	O
Mali	O
close	O
to	O
several	O
world-class	O
gold	O
deposits	O
,	O
including	O
B2Gold	O
’	O
s	O
5.15Moz	O
Fekola	O
gold	O
project	O
30km	O
to	O
the	O
west	O
and	O
Randgold	O
’	O
s	O
12.5Moz	O
Loulo	O
Gold	O
Mine	O
,	O
50km	O
to	O
the	O
north-northwest	O
(	O
Figure	O
2	O
)	O
.	O

Access	O
from	O
the	O
capital	O
city	O
of	O
Bamako	O
is	O
via	O
a	O
high	O
quality	O
sealed	O
road	O
,	O
which	O
passes	O
through	O
the	O
northern	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
project.	O
The	O
tenement	O
is	O
underlain	O
by	O
a	O
Lower	O
Proterozoic	O
Birimian	O
meta-volcanic	O
and	O
meta-sedimentary	O
sequence.	O
A	O
series	O
of	O
dominant	O
NNE-trending	O
faults	O
,	O
displaced	O
by	O
a	O
second	O
set	O
of	O
ESE-trending	O
faults	O
,	O
have	O
been	O
mapped	O
or	O
interpreted	O
from	O
aeromagnetic	O
data.	O
The	O
NNE-trending	O
structures	O
are	O
interpreted	O
as	O
splays	O
emanating	O
from	O
the	O
Senegal	O
Mali	O
Shear	O
Zone	O
(	O
“	O
SMSZ	O
”	O
)	O
,	O
a	O
regional	O
scale	O
NNW-	O
trending	O
strike-slip	O
fault	O
,	O
which	O
plays	O
an	O
important	O
role	O
in	O
controlling	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
in	O
the	O
region.	O
The	O
SMSZ	O
hosts	O
no	O
fewer	O
than	O
six	O
major	O
gold	O
deposits	O
for	O
an	O
endowment	O
estimated	O
at	O
greater	O
than	O
40Moz	O
,	O
including	O
Sadiola	O
(	O
13.5Moz	O
)	O
and	O
Loulo	O
(	O
12.5Moz	O
)	O
.	O

Oklo	O
therefore	O
considers	O
the	O
Dandoko	O
Project	O
to	O
be	O
highly	O
prospective	O
for	O
the	O
discovery	O
of	O
significant	O
gold	O
deposits	O
and	O
places	O
particular	O
emphasis	O
on	O
the	O
importance	O
of	O
NNE-trending	O
faults	O
as	O
mineralising	O
conduits.	O
Figure	O
2	O
:	O
Location	O
and	O
Geological	O
Setting	O
of	O
the	O
Dandoko	O
and	O
Moussala	O
Projects	O
in	O
west	O
Mali	O
Diabarou	O
The	O
Diabarou	O
prospect	O
is	O
contained	O
within	O
a	O
gold-in-soil	O
anomaly	O
that	O
covers	O
an	O
area	O
of	O
1.2km	O
north-	O
east	O
x	O
1.0km	O
east-west	O
(	O
Figure	O
3	O
)	O
.	O

workings	O
have	O
revealed	O

quartz	O

of	O
up	O

3m	O
in	O
thickness	O
extending	O
over	O
600m.	O

IP	O
geophysical	O
survey.	O
Drilling	O
mostly	O
encountered	O
andesite	O
and	O
porphyry	O
andesite	O
with	O
1-2%	O
disseminated	O
pyrite	O
and	O
intercalated	O
,	O
strongly	O
sheared	O
meta-greywacke	O
and	O
schists.	O

gold	O

is	O
associated	O
with	O
strongly	O
weathered	O
schists	O

a	O
structural	O
control	O
,	O

INDEMNIFICATION	O
OF	O
DIRECTORS	O
AND	O
OFFICERS	O
During	O
the	O
year	O
,	O
the	O
Company	O
paid	O
an	O
insurance	O
premium	O
to	O
insure	O
certain	O
directors	O
and	O
officers	O
including	O
Directors	O
named	O
in	O
this	O
report.	O
The	O
Directors	O
and	O
Officers	O
Liability	O
insurance	O
provides	O
cover	O
against	O
all	O
costs	O
and	O
expenses	O
that	O
may	O
be	O
incurred	O
in	O
defending	O
civil	O
or	O
criminal	O
proceedings	O
that	O
fall	O
within	O
the	O
scope	O
of	O
the	O
indemnity	O
and	O
that	O
may	O
be	O
brought	O
against	O
the	O
officers	O
in	O
their	O
capacity	O
as	O
officers	O
of	O
the	O
Group.	O
The	O
insurance	O
policy	O
does	O
not	O
contain	O
details	O
of	O
the	O
premium	O
paid	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
individual	O
officers	O
of	O
the	O
Group.	O
Disclosure	O
of	O
the	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
liability	O
cover	O
and	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
premium	O
is	O
subject	O
to	O
a	O
confidentiality	O
clause	O
under	O
the	O
insurance	O
policy.	O
The	O
Company	O
has	O
not	O
provided	O
any	O
insurance	O
for	O
an	O
auditor	O
of	O
the	O
group.	O
ENVIRONMENTAL	O
REGULATION	O
The	O
Group	O
is	O
aware	O
of	O
its	O
environmental	O
obligations	O
and	O
acts	O
to	O
ensure	O
that	O
its	O
environmental	O
commitments	O
are	O
met.	O
The	O
Group	O
is	O
not	O
currently	O
subject	O
to	O
significant	O
environmental	O
regulation	O
in	O
respect	O
of	O
its	O
activities.	O
The	O
Directors	O
have	O
considered	O
compliance	O
with	O
the	O
National	O
Greenhouse	O
and	O
Energy	O
Reporting	O
Act	O
2007	O
which	O
requires	O
entities	O
to	O

annual	O

gas	O
emissions	O
and	O
energy	O
use.	O

1	O

to	O
30	O

REMUNERATION	O
REPORT	O
(	O
Audited	O
)	O
The	O
information	O
provided	O
in	O
this	O
remuneration	O
report	O
has	O
been	O
audited	O
as	O
required	O
under	O
Section	O
308	O
(	O
3C	O
)	O
of	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001.	O
This	O
report	O
details	O
the	O
nature	O
and	O
amount	O
of	O
remuneration	O
for	O
each	O
director	O
of	O
Oklo	O
Resources	O
Limited	O
and	O
key	O
management	O
personnel.	O

the	O
purposes	O
of	O
this	O
report	O
,	O
Key	O
Management	O
Personnel	O
(	O
“	O
KMP	O
”	O
)	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
are	O
defined	O
as	O
those	O
persons	O
having	O
authority	O
and	O
responsibility	O
for	O
planning	O
,	O
directing	O
and	O
controlling	O
the	O
major	O
activities	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
and	O
the	O
Group	O
,	O
directly	O
or	O
indirectly	O
,	O
including	O
any	O
Director	O
(	O
whether	O
Executive	O
or	O
otherwise	O
)	O
of	O
the	O
parent	O
company.	O

and	O

of	O

REMUNERATION	O
REPORT	O
(	O
Audited	O
)	O
(	O
Cont.	O
)	O
Remuneration	O
Policy	O
The	O
nature	O
and	O
amount	O
of	O
remuneration	O
for	O
the	O
Non-executive	O
Directors	O
and	O
executives	O
depends	O
on	O
the	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
role	O
and	O
market	O
rates	O
for	O
the	O
position	O
,	O
with	O
the	O
assistance	O
of	O
external	O
surveys	O
and	O
reports	O
,	O
taking	O
into	O
account	O
the	O
experience	O
and	O
qualifications	O
of	O
each	O
individual.	O
The	O
Board	O
ensures	O
that	O
the	O
remuneration	O
of	O
key	O
management	O
personnel	O
is	O
competitive	O
and	O
reasonable.	O
Fees	O
and	O
payments	O
to	O
the	O
Non-	O
executive	O
Directors	O
reflect	O
the	O
demands	O
which	O
are	O
made	O
on	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
responsibilities	O
of	O
the	O
Directors.	O
Non-	O
executive	O
Director	O
’	O
s	O
fees	O
and	O
payments	O
are	O
reviewed	O
annually	O
by	O
the	O
Board.	O
In	O
undertaking	O
a	O
review	O
of	O
the	O
performance	O
of	O
both	O
directors	O
and	O
executives	O
,	O
consideration	O
is	O
given	O
to	O
the	O
respective	O
performance	O
of	O
person	O
during	O
the	O
review	O
period	O
;	O
however	O
,	O
there	O
are	O
no	O
prescribed	O
performance	O
measures	O
or	O
hurdles	O
connected	O
with	O
the	O
level	O
of	O
remuneration.	O
Given	O
the	O
current	O
size	O
,	O
nature	O
and	O
risks	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
,	O
incentive	O
options	O
have	O
been	O
used	O
to	O
attract	O
and	O
retain	O
Non-executive	O
Directors	O
and	O
executives.	O
The	O
grant	O
of	O
such	O
options	O
is	O
at	O
the	O
discretion	O
of	O
the	O
Board	O
and	O
subject	O
,	O
as	O
appropriate	O
,	O
to	O
shareholder	O
approval.	O
The	O
Board	O
believes	O
participation	O
in	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
Incentive	O
Option	O
Scheme	O
motivates	O
key	O
management	O
and	O
executives	O
with	O
the	O
long	O
term	O
interests	O
of	O
shareholders.	O
The	O
group	O
has	O
not	O
engaged	O
the	O
services	O
of	O
external	O
remuneration	O
consultants	O
to	O
advise	O
them	O
on	O
Director	O
and	O
executive	O
remuneration	O
policy.	O
At	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
2015	O
Annual	O

Meeting	O
,	O
the	O
Remuneration	O

was	O
passed	O
by	O
way	O
of	O
show	O
of	O
hands	O
and	O
no	O
comment	O
was	O
made	O
on	O
this	O
matter	O
by	O
any	O
attendees.	O

auto	O

(	O

)	O

’	O
REPORT	O
REMUNERATION	O
REPORT	O
(	O
Audited	O
)	O
(	O
Cont.	O
)	O
Securities	O
Trading	O
Policy	O
The	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
security	O
trading	O
policy	O
provides	O
guidance	O
on	O
acceptable	O
transactions	O
in	O
dealing	O
in	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
various	O
securities	O
,	O
including	O
shares	O
,	O
debt	O
notes	O
and	O
options.	O
The	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
security	O
trading	O
policy	O
defines	O
dealing	O
in	O
company	O
securities	O
to	O
include	O
:	O
(	O
a	O
)	O
Subscribing	O
for	O
,	O
purchasing	O
or	O
selling	O
Company	O
Securities	O
or	O
entering	O
into	O
an	O
agreement	O
to	O
do	O
any	O
of	O
those	O
things	O
;	O
(	O
b	O
)	O
Advising	O
,	O
procuring	O
or	O
encouraging	O
another	O
person	O
(	O
including	O
a	O
family	O
member	O
,	O
friend	O
,	O
associate	O
,	O
colleague	O
,	O
family	O
company	O
or	O
family	O
trust	O
)	O
to	O
trade	O
in	O
Company	O
Securities	O
;	O
and	O
(	O
c	O
)	O
Entering	O
into	O
agreements	O
or	O
transactions	O
which	O
operate	O
to	O
limit	O
the	O
economic	O
risk	O
of	O
a	O
person	O
’	O
s	O
holdings	O
in	O
Company	O
Securities.	O
The	O
securities	O
trading	O
policy	O
details	O
acceptable	O
and	O
unacceptable	O
times	O
for	O
trading	O
in	O
Company	O
Securities	O
including	O
detailing	O
potential	O
civil	O
and	O
criminal	O
penalties	O
for	O
misuse	O
of	O
“	O
inside	O
information	O
”	O
.	O

The	O
Directors	O
must	O
not	O
deal	O
in	O
Company	O
Securities	O
without	O
providing	O
written	O
notification	O
to	O
the	O
Chairman.	O
The	O
Chairman	O
must	O
not	O
deal	O
in	O
Company	O
Securities	O
without	O
the	O
prior	O
approval	O
of	O
the	O
Chief	O
Executive	O
Officer.	O
The	O
Directors	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
disclosure	O
to	O
the	O
market	O
of	O
all	O
transactions	O
or	O
contracts	O
involving	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
shares.	O
This	O
is	O
the	O
end	O
of	O
the	O
Audited	O
Remuneration	O
Report.	O
DIRECTORS	O
’	O
MEETINGS	O

table	O
below	O
sets	O
out	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
Directors	O
’	O
meetings	O
held	O
during	O
the	O
period	O
and	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
meetings	O
attended	O
by	O
each	O
as	O
a	O
Director.	O

MEETINGS	O

40	O
2016	O
Annual	O
Report	O
NOTES	O
TO	O
THE	O
CONSOLIDATED	O
FINANCIAL	O
STATEMENTS	O
For	O
the	O
year	O
ended	O
30	O
June	O
2016	O
1.	O
SUMMARY	O
OF	O
SIGNIFICANT	O
ACCOUNTING	O
POLICIES	O
The	O
principal	O
accounting	O
policies	O
adopted	O
in	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
these	O
financial	O
statements	O
are	O
set	O
out	O
below.	O
These	O
policies	O
have	O
been	O
consistently	O
applied	O
to	O
all	O
the	O
years	O
presented	O
,	O
unless	O
otherwise	O
stated.	O
The	O
financial	O
statements	O
for	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
consist	O
of	O
Oklo	O
Resources	O
Limited	O
and	O
its	O
subsidiaries.	O
Statement	O
of	O
compliance	O
The	O
financial	O
statements	O
are	O
general	O
purpose	O
financial	O
statements	O
which	O
have	O
been	O
prepared	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001	O
,	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
and	O
Australian	O
Accounting	O
Interpretations	O
and	O
complies	O
with	O
other	O
requirements	O
of	O
the	O
law.	O
The	O
financial	O
statements	O
and	O
notes	O
of	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
comply	O
with	O
International	O
Financial	O
Reporting	O
Standards	O
(	O
‘	O
IFRS	O
’	O
)	O
.	O

Oklo	O
Resources	O
Limited	O
is	O
a	O
for-profit	O
entity	O
for	O
the	O
purposes	O
of	O
preparing	O
the	O
financial	O
statements.	O
The	O
financial	O
statements	O
were	O
authorised	O
for	O
issue	O
by	O
the	O
Directors	O
on	O
30	O
September	O
2016.	O
Basis	O
of	O
preparation	O
The	O
financial	O
statements	O
have	O
been	O
prepared	O
on	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
historical	O
cost.	O
Cost	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
fair	O
values	O
of	O
the	O
consideration	O
given	O
in	O
exchange	O
for	O
assets.	O
In	O
the	O
application	O
of	O
IFRS	O
,	O
management	O
is	O
required	O
to	O
make	O
judgments	O
,	O
estimates	O
and	O
assumptions	O
about	O
carrying	O
values	O
of	O
assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
that	O
are	O
not	O
readily	O
apparent	O
from	O
other	O
sources.	O
The	O
estimates	O
and	O
associated	O
assumptions	O
are	O
based	O
on	O
historical	O
experience	O
and	O
various	O
other	O
factors	O
that	O
are	O
believed	O
to	O
be	O
reasonable	O
under	O
the	O
circumstance	O
,	O
the	O
results	O
of	O
which	O
form	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
making	O
the	O
judgments.	O
Actual	O
results	O
may	O
differ	O
from	O
these	O
estimates.	O
The	O
estimates	O
and	O
underlying	O
assumptions	O
are	O
reviewed	O
on	O
an	O
ongoing	O
basis.	O
Revisions	O
to	O
accounting	O
estimates	O
are	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
period	O
in	O
which	O
the	O
estimate	O
is	O
revised	O
if	O
the	O
revision	O
affects	O
only	O
that	O
period	O
or	O
in	O
the	O
period	O
of	O
the	O
revision	O
and	O
future	O
periods	O
if	O
the	O
revision	O
affects	O
both	O
current	O
and	O
future	O
periods.	O
Judgments	O
made	O
by	O
management	O
in	O
the	O
application	O
of	O
IFRS	O
that	O
have	O
significant	O
effects	O
on	O
the	O
financial	O
statements	O
and	O
estimates	O
with	O
a	O
significant	O
risk	O
of	O
material	O
adjustments	O
in	O
the	O
next	O
period	O
are	O
disclosed	O
,	O
where	O
applicable	O
,	O
in	O
the	O
relevant	O
notes	O
to	O
the	O
financial	O
statements.	O
New	O
and	O
amended	O
standards	O
adopted	O
by	O
the	O
group	O
The	O
group	O
has	O
applied	O
the	O
following	O
standards	O
and	O
amendments	O
for	O
the	O
first	O
time	O
for	O
the	O
annual	O
reporting	O
period	O
commencing	O
1	O
July	O
2015	O
:	O
•	O

Interpretation	O
21	O
Accounting	O
for	O
Levies	O
•	O

AASB	O
2013-3	O
Amendments	O
to	O
AASB	O
136	O
–	O

Recoverable	O
Amount	O
Disclosures	O
for	O
Non-	O
Financial	O
Assets	O
•	O

AASB	O
2013-4	O
Amendments	O
to	O
Australian	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
–	O

Novation	O
of	O
Derivatives	O
and	O
Continuation	O
of	O
Hedge	O
Accounting	O
•	O

AASB	O
2015-1	O
Amendments	O
to	O
Australian	O
Accounting	O
Standards.	O
The	O
adoption	O
of	O
these	O
standards	O
has	O
not	O
resulted	O
in	O
changes	O
in	O
accounting	O
policies	O
that	O
have	O
resulted	O
in	O
adjustments	O
to	O
the	O
amounts	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O
financial	O
statements.	O
Oklo	O

Entities	O

the	O
year	O
ended	O
