Page	O
25	O
NOTES	O
TO	O
THE	O
CONSOLIDATED	O
FINANCIAL	O
STATEMENTS	O
(	O
CONTINUED	O
)	O
1	O
:	O
SUMMARY	O
OF	O
SIGNIFICANT	O
ACCOUNTING	O
POLICIES	O
The	O
principal	O
accounting	O
policies	O
adopted	O
in	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
statements	O
are	O
set	O
out	O
below.	O
The	O
financial	O
statements	O
are	O
for	O
the	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
consisting	O
of	O
Lefroy	O
Exploration	O
Limited	O
and	O
its	O
subsidiaries	O
(	O
“	O
the	O
Group	O
”	O
or	O
“	O
consolidated	O
entity	O
”	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
financial	O
statements	O
are	O
presented	O
in	O
Australian	O
dollars.	O
Lefroy	O
Exploration	O
Limited	O
is	O
a	O
company	O
limited	O
by	O
shares	O
,	O
incorporated	O
in	O
and	O
under	O
the	O
laws	O
of	O
the	O
British	O
Virgin	O
Islands	O
on	O
14	O
May	O
1990	O
under	O
the	O
International	O
Business	O
Act	O
(	O
Cap.	O
291	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
Company	O
maintains	O
registered	O
offices	O
in	O
Western	O
Australian	O
and	O
the	O
British	O
Virgin	O
Islands.	O
The	O
financial	O
statements	O
were	O
authorised	O
for	O
issue	O
by	O
the	O
directors	O
on	O
27	O
September	O
2019.	O
The	O
directors	O
have	O
the	O
power	O
to	O
amend	O
and	O
reissue	O
the	O
financial	O
statements.	O
(	O
a	O
)	O
Basis	O
of	O
preparation	O
These	O
financial	O
statements	O
have	O
been	O
prepared	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
International	O
Financial	O
Reporting	O
Standards	O
(	O
“	O
IFRS	O
”	O
)	O
as	O
issued	O
by	O
the	O
International	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
Board	O
(	O
“	O
IASB	O
”	O
)	O
.	O

Lefroy	O
Exploration	O
Limited	O
is	O
a	O
for-profit	O
entity	O
for	O
the	O
purpose	O
of	O
preparing	O
the	O
financial	O
statements.	O
(	O
i	O
)	O
New	O
and	O
amended	O
standards	O
adopted	O
by	O
the	O
Group	O
IFRS	O
15	O
Revenue	O
from	O
Contracts	O
with	O
Customers	O
IFRS	O
15	O
and	O
its	O
related	O
amendments	O
supersede	O
IAS	O
11	O
Construction	O
Contracts	O
,	O
IAS	O
18	O
Revenue	O
and	O
related	O
Interpretations.	O
It	O
applies	O
to	O
all	O
revenue	O
arising	O
from	O
contracts	O
with	O
its	O
customers	O
and	O
became	O
effective	O
for	O
annual	O
periods	O
beginning	O
on	O
or	O
after	O
1	O
January	O
2018.	O
IFRS	O
15	O
establishes	O
a	O
five-step	O
model	O
to	O
account	O
for	O
revenue	O
arising	O
from	O
contracts	O
with	O
customers.	O
It	O
requires	O
revenue	O
to	O
be	O
recognised	O
when	O
(	O
or	O
as	O
)	O
control	O
of	O
a	O
good	O
or	O
service	O
transfers	O
to	O
a	O
customer	O
at	O
an	O
amount	O
that	O
reflects	O
the	O
consideration	O
to	O
which	O
an	O
entity	O
expects	O
to	O
be	O
entitled	O
in	O
exchange	O
for	O
transferring	O
goods	O
or	O
services	O
to	O
a	O
customer.	O
IFRS	O
15	O
requires	O
entities	O
to	O
exercise	O
judgement	O
,	O
taking	O
into	O
consideration	O
all	O
of	O
the	O
relevant	O
facts	O
and	O
circumstances	O
when	O
applying	O
each	O
step	O
of	O
the	O
model	O
to	O
contracts	O
with	O
their	O
customers.	O
The	O
standard	O
also	O
specifies	O
the	O
accounting	O
for	O
the	O
incremental	O
costs	O
of	O
obtaining	O
a	O
contract	O
and	O
the	O
costs	O
directly	O
related	O
to	O
fulfilling	O
a	O
contract.	O
In	O
addition	O
,	O
the	O
standard	O
requires	O
enhanced	O
and	O
extensive	O
disclosures	O
about	O
revenue	O
to	O
help	O
investors	O
better	O
understand	O
the	O
nature	O
,	O
amount	O
,	O
timing	O
and	O
uncertainty	O
of	O
revenue	O
and	O
cash	O
flows	O
from	O
contracts	O
with	O
customers.	O
The	O
Group	O
adopted	O
IFRS	O
15	O
using	O
the	O
full	O
retrospective	O
method	O
of	O
adoption.	O
The	O
change	O
did	O
not	O
have	O
a	O
material	O
impact	O
on	O
the	O
statement	O
of	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
and	O
other	O
comprehensive	O
income	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
as	O
the	O
Group	O
does	O
not	O
generate	O
revenue	O
from	O
contracts	O
with	O
customers.	O
There	O
was	O
no	O
net	O
impact	O
on	O
the	O
statement	O
of	O
cash	O
flows.	O
There	O
was	O
no	O
impact	O
on	O
EPS.	O
IFRS	O
9	O
Financial	O
Instruments	O
Measurement	O
and	O
classification	O
IFRS	O
9	O
Financial	O
Instruments	O
replaces	O
IAS	O
39	O
Financial	O
Instruments	O
:	O
Recognition	O
and	O
Measurement	O
for	O
annual	O
periods	O
beginning	O
on	O
or	O
after	O
1	O
January	O
2018	O
,	O
bringing	O
together	O
all	O
three	O
aspects	O
of	O
the	O
accounting	O
for	O
financial	O
instruments	O
:	O
classification	O
and	O
measurement	O
;	O
impairment	O
;	O
and	O
hedge	O
accounting.	O
Under	O
IFRS	O
9	O
,	O
debt	O
instruments	O
are	O
subsequently	O
measured	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
(	O
FVTPL	O
)	O
,	O
amortised	O
cost	O
or	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
other	O
comprehensive	O
income	O
(	O
FVOCI	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
classification	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
two	O
criteria	O
,	O
the	O
Group's	O
business	O
model	O
for	O
managing	O
the	O
assets	O
and	O
whether	O
the	O
instruments	O
’	O
contractual	O
cash	O
flows	O
represent	O
‘	O
solely	O
payments	O
of	O
principal	O
and	O
interest	O
’	O
on	O
the	O
principal	O
amount	O
outstanding	O
(	O
the	O
‘	O
SPPI	O
’	O
criterion	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
Group	O
has	O
applied	O
IFRS	O
9	O
retrospectively	O
,	O
with	O
the	O
initial	O
application	O
date	O
of	O
1	O
July	O
2018.	O
There	O
was	O
no	O
material	O
impacts	O
on	O
the	O
comparative	O
balances	O
as	O
the	O
Group	O
and	O
the	O
Group	O
elected	O
not	O
to	O
restate	O
comparative	O
information	O
as	O
allowed	O
under	O
IFRS	O
9.	O
On	O
transition	O
,	O
although	O
there	O
were	O
changes	O
to	O
the	O
measurement	O
categories	O
of	O
certain	O
financial	O
instruments	O
presented	O
in	O
the	O
statement	O
of	O
financial	O
position	O
,	O
this	O
did	O
not	O
result	O
in	O
a	O
material	O
change	O
to	O
their	O
basis	O
of	O
measurement	O
as	O
previously	O
applied	O
under	O
IAS	O
39.	O
The	O
Group	O
has	O
determined	O
that	O
the	O
adoption	O
of	O
AASB	O
9	O
has	O
impacted	O
the	O
classification	O
of	O
financial	O
instruments	O
at	O
1	O
July	O
2018	O
as	O
follows	O
:	O

(	O

)	O

)	O
Impairment	O
of	O
assets	O
In	O
relation	O
to	O
financial	O
assets	O
carried	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
,	O
IFRS	O
9	O
requires	O
a	O
forward-looking	O
expected	O
credit	O
loss	O
(	O
‘	O
ECL	O
’	O
)	O
model	O
to	O
be	O
applied	O
as	O
opposed	O
to	O
an	O
incurred	O
credit	O
loss	O
model	O
under	O
IAS	O
39.	O
The	O
expected	O
credit	O
loss	O
model	O
requires	O
the	O
Group	O
to	O
account	O
for	O
expected	O
credit	O
losses	O
and	O
changes	O
in	O
those	O
expected	O
credit	O
losses	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date	O
to	O
reflect	O
the	O
changes	O
in	O
credit	O
risk	O
since	O
initial	O
recognition	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
asset.	O
As	O
at	O
1	O
July	O
2018	O
,	O
the	O
Group	O
has	O
reviewed	O
and	O
assessed	O
the	O
existing	O
financial	O
assets	O
for	O
impairment	O
using	O
reasonable	O
and	O
supportable	O
information	O
as	O
to	O
their	O
associated	O
credit	O
risk.	O
The	O
Group	O
concluded	O
that	O
the	O
relevant	O
financial	O
assets	O
measured	O
at	O
amortised	O
cost	O
,	O
as	O
noted	O
in	O
the	O
table	O
above	O
,	O
are	O
of	O
low	O
credit	O
risk	O
,	O
or	O
the	O
lifetime	O
ECL	O
associated	O
with	O
the	O
financial	O
asset	O
would	O
be	O
negligible.	O
The	O
Group	O
has	O
credit	O
rating	O
and	O
risk	O
management	O
policies	O
in	O
place	O
,	O
the	O
change	O
to	O
a	O

loss	O
approach	O
did	O
not	O

a	O

on	O

amounts	O
recognised	O
in	O
the	O

the	O

is	O

.	O

no	O

upon	O

of	O
IFRS	O
9	O
by	O
the	O
Group.	O
(	O
ii	O
)	O
Early	O

of	O
standards	O

did	O
not	O

before	O
their	O

1	O

)	O
Historical	O
cost	O
convention	O

for	O

assets	O

have	O

value	O
these	O

statements	O
have	O
been	O
prepared	O
under	O
the	O

cost	O
convention.	O
(	O
iv	O
)	O
Going	O
concern	O
The	O
consolidated	O
financial	O
statements	O
have	O
been	O
prepared	O
on	O
a	O
going	O
concern	O
basis	O
which	O
contemplates	O
the	O
continuity	O
of	O
normal	O
business	O
activities	O
and	O
the	O
realisation	O
of	O
assets	O
and	O
the	O
settlement	O
of	O
liabilities	O
in	O
the	O
normal	O
course	O
of	O
business.	O
Subsequent	O
to	O
year	O
end	O
,	O
the	O
Group	O
raised	O
$3.8	O
million	O
before	O
costs	O
through	O
a	O
share	O
placement	O
to	O
sophisticated	O
and	O
institutional	O
investors.	O
Refer	O
to	O
Note	O
23	O
for	O
further	O
details.	O
The	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
cash	O
flow	O
forecasts	O
through	O
to	O
30	O
September	O
2020	O

above	O
capital	O
raising	O
,	O
reflect	O
that	O
the	O
Group	O
has	O
sufficient	O
working	O
capital	O
to	O
enable	O
it	O
to	O
meet	O
its	O
committed	O
administration	O
,	O
exploration	O
and	O
operational	O
expenditure	O
over	O
this	O
period.	O

,	O
the	O
directors	O
consider	O
it	O
appropriate	O
to	O
prepare	O
the	O
financial	O
statements	O
on	O
a	O
going	O
concern	O
basis.	O

27	O
NOTES	O
TO	O
THE	O
CONSOLIDATED	O
FINANCIAL	O
STATEMENTS	O
(	O
CONTINUED	O
)	O
(	O
b	O
)	O
Principles	O
of	O
consolidation	O
(	O
i	O
)	O
Subsidiaries	O
The	O
consolidated	O
financial	O
statements	O
incorporate	O

assets	O
and	O
liabilities	O
of	O
all	O
subsidiaries	O
of	O
Lefroy	O
Exploration	O
Limited	O
(	O
“	O
Company	O
”	O
or	O
“	O
parent	O
entity	O
”	O
)	O
as	O
at	O
30	O
June	O
2019	O
and	O
the	O
results	O
of	O
all	O
subsidiaries	O
for	O
the	O
year	O
then	O

Lefroy	O
Exploration	O
Limited	O
and	O
its	O

to	O
in	O
these	O

as	O
the	O
Group	O
or	O
the	O

over	O

or	O
has	O

to	O
variable	O

from	O

with	O
the	O
investee	O
and	O
has	O

to	O

returns	O
through	O
its	O

over	O

Gorup	O
controls	O
a	O

if	O

,	O

:	O
	O

Power	O
over	O

	O

Exposure	O
,	O

rights	O
,	O
to	O
variable	O

from	O

	O

The	O

The	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O

The	O

of	O

of	O

)	O
Changes	O
in	O
ownership	O
interests	O
The	O
Group	O

)	O
Income	O
tax	O
The	O
income	O

or	O

is	O

current	O

’	O
s	O

on	O
the	O

income	O
tax	O
rate	O
for	O
each	O
jurisdiction	O
adjusted	O
by	O
changes	O
in	O
deferred	O
tax	O
assets	O
and	O

to	O
temporary	O
differences	O
and	O
to	O
unused	O
tax	O
losses.	O
The	O

income	O

on	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
the	O
tax	O
laws	O
enacted	O

and	O

in	O

to	O

which	O

where	O

on	O

of	O

to	O

the	O

in	O

the	O
liability	O
method	O
,	O

Deferred	O

not	O

if	O
it	O
arises	O
from	O
initial	O
recognition	O
of	O
an	O
asset	O
or	O

in	O
a	O
transaction	O
other	O
than	O
a	O

of	O

(	O
and	O
laws	O
)	O
that	O
have	O

asset	O

is	O

Deferred	O
tax	O

for	O

and	O

Deferred	O

Impairment	O

which	O

’	O

is	O
the	O
higher	O
of	O
an	O
asset	O
’	O

fair	O
value	O
less	O

to	O

and	O
value	O
in	O

Financial	O

assets	O

income	O
(	O

)	O
,	O
or	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
profit	O
and	O
loss.	O
The	O
classification	O
of	O
financial	O
instruments	O
at	O
initial	O
recognition	O
depends	O
on	O
the	O
financial	O

’	O
s	O
contractual	O
cashflow	O
characteristics	O
and	O

at	O

through	O

and	O
loss	O
,	O
less	O
transaction	O
costs.	O
Trade	O
Receivables	O
Trade	O
receivables	O
that	O
do	O
not	O
contain	O
a	O
significant	O
financing	O
component	O
are	O
measured	O
at	O
the	O
transaction	O
price	O
determined	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
accounting	O
policy	O
for	O
revenue	O
recognition.	O
For	O
trade	O
receivables	O
,	O

Group	O
applies	O
a	O
simplified	O
approach	O
in	O
calculating	O
ECLs.	O
Therefore	O
,	O
the	O
Group	O
does	O
not	O
track	O
changes	O
in	O
credit	O
risk	O
,	O
but	O
instead	O
recognises	O
a	O
loss	O
allowance	O
based	O
on	O
lifetime	O
ECLs	O
at	O
each	O
reporting	O
date.	O
In	O
determining	O
the	O
provision	O
required	O
,	O
the	O
Group	O
utilises	O
its	O
historical	O
credit	O
loss	O
experience	O
,	O
adjusted	O
only	O
where	O
appropriate	O
for	O
forward-looking	O
factors	O
specific	O
to	O
the	O
debtors	O
and	O
economic	O
environment.	O
The	O
Group	O
considers	O
a	O
financial	O
asset	O
in	O
default	O
when	O
contractual	O
payments	O
are	O
90	O
days	O
past	O
due.	O
However	O
,	O
in	O
certain	O
cases	O
,	O
the	O
Group	O
may	O
also	O
consider	O
a	O
financial	O
asset	O
to	O
be	O
in	O
default	O
when	O
internal	O
or	O
external	O
information	O
indicates	O
that	O
the	O
Group	O
is	O
unlikely	O
to	O
receive	O
the	O
outstanding	O
contractual	O
amounts	O
in	O
full	O
before	O
taking	O
into	O
account	O
any	O
credit	O
enhancements	O
held	O
by	O
the	O
Group.	O
A	O
financial	O
asset	O
is	O
written	O
off	O
when	O
there	O
is	O
no	O
reasonable	O
expectation	O
of	O
recovery.	O
Indicators	O
that	O
there	O
is	O
no	O
reasonable	O
expectation	O
of	O
recovery	O
include	O
,	O
amongst	O
others	O
,	O
the	O
failure	O
of	O
a	O
debtor	O
to	O
engage	O
in	O
a	O
repayment	O
plan	O
with	O
the	O
Group	O
,	O
and	O
a	O
failure	O
to	O
make	O
contractual	O
payments	O
for	O
a	O
period	O
of	O
greater	O
than	O
120	O
days	O
past	O
due.	O
There	O
are	O
no	O
material	O
trade	O
receivable	O
for	O
the	O
Group	O
as	O
it	O
does	O
not	O
generate	O
revenues.	O
Financial	O
assets	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
Financial	O
assets	O
are	O
classified	O
at	O
“	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
”	O
Financial	O
assets	O
are	O
classified	O
at	O
“	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
”	O
include	O
financial	O
assets	O
held	O
for	O
trading	O
,	O
financial	O
assets	O
designated	O
upon	O
initial	O
recognition	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
,	O
or	O
financial	O
assets	O
mandatorily	O
required	O
to	O
be	O
measured	O
at	O
fair	O
value.	O
Financial	O
assets	O
are	O
classified	O
as	O
held	O
for	O
trading	O
if	O
they	O
are	O
acquired	O
for	O
the	O
purpose	O
of	O
selling	O
or	O
repurchasing	O
in	O
the	O
near	O
term.	O
Derivatives	O
,	O
including	O
separated	O
embedded	O
derivatives	O
,	O
are	O
also	O
classified	O
as	O
held	O
for	O
trading	O
unless	O
they	O
are	O
designated	O
as	O
effective	O
hedging	O
instruments.	O
The	O
group	O
hold	O
derivative	O
instruments	O
,	O
which	O
are	O
not	O
held	O
for	O
trading	O
,	O
and	O
equity	O
investments	O
which	O
are	O
both	O
mandatorily	O
classified	O
as	O
“	O
fair	O
value	O
through	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
”	O
.	O

Such	O
assets	O
are	O
measured	O
at	O
fair	O
value	O
with	O
changes	O
in	O
carrying	O
amount	O
being	O
included	O
in	O
profit	O
or	O
loss.	O
Fair	O
value	O
is	O
the	O
price	O
the	O
Group	O
would	O
receive	O
to	O
sell	O
an	O
asset	O
or	O
would	O
have	O
to	O
pay	O
to	O
transfer	O
a	O
liability	O
in	O
an	O
orderly	O
transaction	O
between	O
independent	O
,	O
knowledgeable	O
and	O
willing	O
market	O
participants	O
at	O
the	O
measurement	O
date.	O
(	O
i	O
)	O
Plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
All	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
is	O
stated	O
at	O
historical	O
cost	O
less	O
accumulated	O
depreciation.	O
Historical	O
cost	O
includes	O
expenditure	O
that	O
is	O
directly	O
attributable	O
to	O
the	O
acquisition	O
of	O
the	O
items.	O
Subsequent	O
costs	O
are	O
included	O
in	O
the	O
asset	O
’	O
s	O
carrying	O
amount	O
or	O
recognised	O
as	O
a	O
separate	O
asset	O
,	O
as	O
appropriate	O
,	O
only	O
when	O
it	O
is	O
probable	O
that	O
future	O
economic	O
benefits	O
associated	O
with	O
the	O
item	O
will	O
flow	O
to	O
the	O
Group	O
and	O
the	O
cost	O
of	O
the	O
item	O
can	O
be	O
measured	O
reliably.	O
The	O

amount	O
of	O
any	O
component	O
accounted	O
for	O
as	O
a	O
separate	O
asset	O

All	O

and	O

are	O

to	O

of	O
profit	O
or	O
loss	O
and	O
other	O
comprehensive	O
income	O
during	O
the	O
reporting	O
period	O
in	O
which	O
they	O
are	O
incurred.	O
Depreciation	O
of	O
plant	O
and	O
equipment	O
is	O

using	O
the	O
straight-line	O
method	O
to	O
allocate	O
their	O
cost	O
,	O
net	O
of	O
their	O
residual	O
values	O
,	O
over	O
their	O
estimated	O
useful	O
lives	O
or	O
,	O

and	O

shorter	O

term.	O

per	O

)	O
.	O

The	O

(	O
i	O
)	O
the	O

to	O

ii	O
)	O

that	O

opinion	O
of	O

of	O

Group	O
,	O
will	O
ultimately	O
vest.	O
This	O
opinion	O
is	O
formed	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
best	O
available	O
information	O
at	O
balance	O
date.	O
No	O
adjustment	O
is	O
made	O
for	O
the	O
likelihood	O
of	O
market	O
performance	O
conditions	O
being	O
met	O
as	O
the	O
effect	O
of	O
these	O
conditions	O
is	O
included	O
in	O
the	O
determination	O
of	O
fair	O
value	O
at	O
grant	O
date.	O
No	O
expense	O
is	O
recognised	O
for	O
rights	O
that	O
do	O
not	O
ultimately	O
vest	O
,	O
except	O
for	O
rights	O
where	O

is	O
conditional	O
upon	O
a	O
market	O
condition.	O

is	O

is	O
treated	O
as	O
if	O

had	O

on	O
the	O
date	O
of	O

and	O
any	O
expense	O
not	O
yet	O
recognised	O
for	O
the	O
right	O
is	O
recognised	O
immediately.	O
However	O
,	O
if	O

option	O

for	O

of	O

circumstances	O
,	O
in	O
particular	O
whether	O
an	O

viable	O
extraction	O
operation	O
can	O
be	O
established.	O

and	O
assumptions	O
may	O

as	O

information	O
becomes	O
available.	O

to	O

Credit	O

The	O

Level	O
1	O
:	O
The	O
fair	O
value	O
is	O

using	O

prices	O
in	O
active	O
markets	O
for	O
identical	O
assets	O
or	O
liabilities.	O
Level	O
2	O
:	O

fair	O
value	O
is	O
estimated	O
using	O
inputs	O
other	O
than	O
quotes	O
prices	O
included	O
in	O
level	O
1	O
that	O
are	O

for	O

asset	O
or	O

(	O
as	O
prices	O
)	O
or	O
indirectly	O
(	O
derived	O
from	O
prices	O
)	O
.	O

Level	O
3	O
:	O

fair	O
value	O
is	O
estimated	O
using	O
valuation	O
techniques	O
for	O
which	O
the	O
lowest	O
level	O
input	O
that	O
is	O
significant	O
to	O
the	O
fair	O
value	O
measurement	O

CAPITAL	O

(	O

Ordinary	O

Ordinary	O

paid	O
shares	O
entitle	O
the	O
holder	O
to	O
participate	O
in	O
dividends	O
and	O

proceeds	O
on	O

up	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
in	O
proportion	O
to	O
the	O
number	O
of	O

shares	O

On	O
a	O
show	O
of	O
hands	O
every	O
holder	O
of	O
ordinary	O
fully	O
paid	O
shares	O
present	O
at	O
a	O

in	O
person	O

is	O
entitled	O
to	O
one	O

and	O
upon	O
a	O
poll	O
is	O
entitled	O
to	O
one	O
vote	O
for	O
each	O
share	O
held.	O
(	O
c	O
)	O
Capital	O
risk	O
management	O
The	O
Group	O
defines	O
capital	O
as	O
issued	O
share	O
capital.	O
Its	O
objective	O
when	O
managing	O
capital	O
is	O
to	O
safeguard	O
its	O
ability	O
to	O
continue	O
as	O
a	O
going	O
concern	O
,	O
so	O
that	O
it	O
may	O
strive	O
to	O
provide	O
returns	O
for	O
shareholders	O
and	O
benefits	O
for	O
other	O
stakeholders.	O
Due	O
to	O
the	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
activities	O
,	O
being	O
mineral	O
exploration	O
,	O
the	O
Group	O
does	O
not	O
have	O
ready	O
access	O
to	O
credit	O
facilities	O
,	O
with	O
the	O
primary	O
source	O
of	O
funding	O
being	O
equity	O
raisings.	O
Therefore	O
,	O
the	O
focus	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
capital	O
risk	O
management	O
is	O
the	O
current	O
working	O
capital	O
position	O
against	O
the	O
requirements	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
to	O
meet	O
exploration	O
programmes	O
and	O
corporate	O
overheads.	O
The	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
strategy	O
is	O
to	O
ensure	O
appropriate	O
liquidity	O
is	O
maintained	O
to	O
meet	O
anticipated	O
operating	O
requirements	O
,	O
with	O
a	O
view	O
to	O
initiating	O
appropriate	O
capital	O
raisings	O
as	O
required.	O
The	O
working	O
capital	O
position	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
at	O
30	O
June	O
2019	O
and	O
30	O
June	O
2018	O
are	O
as	O

:	O

234	O
(	O
b	O
)	O
Nature	O
and	O
purpose	O
of	O
reserves	O
(	O
i	O
)	O
Foreign	O

reserve	O
The	O

statements	O

currency	O

periods	O
when	O
the	O

and	O
presentation	O
currencies	O

The	O
Lord	O
Nelson	O
deposit	O
occurs	O
along	O
the	O
north-northwest	O
striking	O
shear	O
zone	O
(	O
Trafalgar	O
shear	O
zone	O
)	O
.	O

The	O
deposit	O
is	O
hosted	O
by	O
granodiorite	O
(	O
containing	O
unmineralised	O
basaltic	O
xenolith	O
)	O
intrusive	O
rocks	O
above	O
a	O
footwall	O
ultramafic	O
unit.	O
The	O
quartz-sulphide	O
(	O
mainly	O
pyrite	O
)	O
veining	O
mineralisation	O
trends	O
north-northwest	O
,	O
dipping	O
approximately	O
50	O
°	O

to	O
the	O
west	O
,	O
with	O
a	O
shallow	O
south-southeast	O
plunge	O
that	O
follows	O
the	O
ultramafic	O
footwall	O
contact.	O

1	O
,	O
500m	O
of	O
exploration	O
step	O
out	O
RC	O
drilling	O
,	O
on	O
40m	O
-	O

80m	O
spacing	O
,	O
commenced	O
in	O
mid	O
February.	O

step	O
out	O
drilling	O

the	O
strike	O
extensions	O
of	O

mineralisation	O

of	O

,	O

,	O
potential	O

thereof	O

1	O

1	O
m	O
calico	O

(	O

)	O
.	O

the	O

5	O
m	O

sample	O
was	O

1	O

were	O

•	O

Alto	O
’	O
s	O

RC	O

a	O

350	O

onboard	O
1100/350	O
compressor	O

hammer	O
of	O
nominal	O
140mm	O
hole.	O
•	O

The	O
2017	O
Mineral	O
Resource	O
Estimate	O
for	O
Lord	O
Nelson	O
was	O
based	O
on	O
260	O
reverse	O
circulation	O
(	O
RC	O
)	O
and	O
18	O
diamond	O
drill	O
holes	O
(	O
DDH	O
)	O
and	O
18	O
rotary	O
air	O
blast	O
(	O
RAB	O
)	O
drill	O
holes.	O
RAB	O
drill	O
holes	O
were	O
used	O
to	O
guide	O
mineralisation	O
interpretation	O
and	O
excluded	O
for	O
estimation	O
purposes.	O
•	O

For	O
diamond	O
drilling	O
,	O
triple	O
tube	O
coring	O
was	O
used	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
friable	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
oxide	O
zone	O
lithologies	O
being	O
drilled.	O
The	O
angled	O
core	O
holes	O
were	O
orientated	O
where	O
possible	O
using	O
a	O
crayon	O
marker	O
spear	O
tool	O
and	O
the	O
holes	O
were	O
regularly	O
surveyed	O
using	O
an	O
Eastman	O
downhole	O
camera.	O
Due	O
to	O
the	O
deeply	O
weathered	O
,	O
soft	O
and	O
friable	O
nature	O
of	O
the	O
core	O
,	O
most	O
of	O
the	O
orientations	O
either	O
failed	O
or	O
could	O
not	O
be	O
pieced	O
together	O
over	O
any	O
useful	O
continuous	O
lengths.	O
Drill	O
sample	O
•	O

3kg	O

Alto	O
’	O
s	O
4m	O
RC	O
samples	O
(	O
2020	O
current	O
RC	O
program	O
)	O
Samples	O
submitted	O
for	O
analysis	O
via	O
Photon	O
assay	O
technique	O
were	O
dried	O
,	O
crushed	O
to	O
nominal	O
85%	O
passing	O
2mm	O
,	O
linear	O
split	O
and	O
a	O
nominal	O
500g	O
sub	O
sample	O
taken	O
(	O
method	O
code	O
PAP3512R	O
)	O
•	O

The	O
500g	O
sample	O
is	O
assayed	O
for	O
gold	O
by	O
PhotonAssay	O
(	O
method	O
code	O
PAAU2	O
)	O
along	O
with	O
quality	O
control	O
samples	O
including	O
certified	O
reference	O
materials	O
,	O
blanks	O
and	O
sample	O
duplicates.	O
•	O

About	O
the	O
MinAnalytical	O
Photon	O
Assay	O
Analysis	O
Technique	O
:	O
Developed	O
by	O
CSIRO	O
and	O
the	O
Chrysos	O
Corporation	O
,	O
the	O
Photon	O
Assay	O
technique	O
is	O
a	O
fast	O
o	O

and	O
chemical	O
free	O
alternative	O
to	O
the	O
traditional	O
fire	O
assay	O
process	O
and	O
utilizes	O
high	O
energy	O
x-rays.	O
The	O
process	O
is	O
nondestructive	O
on	O
and	O
utilises	O
a	O
significantly	O
larger	O
sample	O
than	O
the	O
conventional	O
50g	O
fire	O
assay.	O
MinAnalytical	O

For	O
Troy	O
,	O
drill	O

approximately	O
2	O
kg	O
of	O
material	O

a	O

bag.	O
After	O

samples	O
were	O
dried	O
,	O
six	O
bags	O
were	O
placed	O
in	O
a	O
larger	O
plastic	O

bag	O
that	O
ass	O
labelled	O

the	O

address	O

were	O

three	O
times	O
per	O

of	O
samples	O
and	O
analyses	O
to	O
be	O
conducted.	O

was	O

to	O
the	O
laboratory	O
and	O
to	O
the	O
database	O
technician	O
in	O
Troy	O
’	O
s	O
Perth	O
office.	O
•	O

were	O
picked	O
up	O

a	O
courier	O
firm	O
,	O
who	O
counted	O
the	O

of	O

bags	O
before	O

to	O
the	O

Magnet	O
depot	O
150	O
km	O
to	O
the	O
west	O
of	O
Sandstone.	O

the	O
samples	O
were	O
picked	O
up	O
by	O
the	O
courier	O
’	O
s	O
road	O
train	O
and	O
taken	O
to	O
the	O
Perth	O
depot	O
before	O

to	O
the	O
lab.	O
•	O

from	O

form.	O

The	O
Lord	O
Nelson	O
deposit	O
occurs	O
along	O
the	O
north-south	O
trending	O
Trafalgar	O
shear	O
zone.	O
•	O

The	O
Lord	O
Nelson	O
deposit	O
is	O
hosted	O
within	O
a	O
zone	O
of	O
intermixed	O
high-magnesium	O
basalt	O
and	O
granodiorite	O
intrusive	O
rocks	O
above	O
a	O
footwall	O
ultramafic	O
unit.	O
The	O
mineralisation	O
trends	O
north-	O
north-west	O
,	O
dipping	O
approximately	O
50	O
°	O

to	O
the	O
west	O
increasing	O
to	O
70	O
°	O

with	O
depth.	O
The	O
main	O
eastern	O
lode	O
is	O
a	O
zone	O
of	O
pyrite	O
+	O
silica	O
+	O
biotite	O
+/-	O
quartz	O
veining	O
that	O
follows	O
the	O
ultramafic	O
footwall	O
contact.	O
West-northwest	O
striking	O
veins	O
and	O
a	O
sheeted	O
swarm	O
of	O
granodiorite	O
intrusions	O
at	O
Lord	O
Nelson	O
are	O
oblique	O
to	O
the	O
north-northwest	O
trend	O
of	O
the	O
ore	O
envelope	O
inferred	O
from	O
drilling.	O
This	O
suggests	O
that	O
within	O
the	O
ore	O
zone	O
the	O
sheeted	O
veins	O
may	O
produce	O
sub-horizontal	O
shoots	O
oriented	O
west	O
northwest.	O
•	O

Snowden	O
estimated	O
gold	O
grades	O
using	O
ordinary	O
block	O
kriging	O
(	O
parent	O
cell	O
estimates	O
)	O
using	O
modelling	O
CAE	O
Datamine	O
Studio	O
3	O
software.	O
Due	O
to	O
the	O
variable	O
dip	O
of	O
the	O
mineralisation	O
,	O
dynamic	O
techniques	O
anisotropy	O
was	O
used	O
to	O
locally	O

the	O
orientation	O
of	O
the	O
search	O
ellipse	O
and	O
variogram	O
models.	O
•	O

The	O
statistical	O
analysis	O
shows	O
that	O
the	O
main	O
mineralised	O
domains	O
have	O
positively	O
skewed	O
gold	O
distributions	O
with	O
high	O
coefficients	O
of	O
variation	O
(	O
CV	O
)	O
,	O
indicating	O
there	O
are	O
outliers	O
in	O
the	O
domains	O
which	O
have	O
the	O
potential	O
to	O
cause	O
local	O
over	O
estimation.	O
As	O
a	O
result	O
,	O
a	O
top	O
cut	O
of	O
30	O
g/t	O
Au	O
was	O
applied	O
to	O
these	O
domains	O
prior	O
to	O
estimation.	O
This	O
top	O
cut	O
impacts	O
around	O
1%	O
of	O
the	O
composites.	O
The	O
CV	O
for	O
these	O
domains	O
is	O
still	O
slightly	O
elevated	O
after	O
top	O
cutting	O
,	O
however	O
review	O
of	O
the	O
high	O
grade	O
outliers	O
shows	O
that	O
they	O
are	O
located	O
in	O
the	O
centre	O
of	O
the	O
mined	O
out	O
portion	O
of	O
the	O
open	O
pit	O
and	O
as	O
such	O
will	O
have	O
no	O
influence	O
on	O
the	O
Mineral	O
Resource.	O

a	O
result	O
,	O

considers	O
that	O
ordinary	O

with	O
a	O
top	O
cut	O
is	O
an	O
appropriate	O
estimation	O
technique	O
for	O
these	O
domains.	O
The	O
near	O

flat	O

mineralisation	O
is	O
lower	O
grade	O
and	O
less	O
skewed.	O
A	O

cut	O
of	O
6	O
g/t	O
Au	O
was	O
applied	O
to	O
this	O
domain	O
prior	O
to	O
estimation.	O
•	O

Boundaries	O
between	O
the	O
mineralised	O
domains	O
were	O
treated	O
as	O
hard	O
for	O
estimation.	O
•	O

A	O
block	O
model	O
was	O

using	O
a	O
parent	O
block	O
size	O
of	O
5	O
mE	O
by	O
10	O
mN	O
by	O
5	O
mRL	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
nominal	O
drill	O
hole	O

along	O
with	O
an	O
assessment	O
of	O
the	O
grade	O
continuity	O
using	O
a	O
kriging	O
neighbourhood	O
analysis.	O
•	O

initial	O
search	O
ellipse	O
of	O
40	O
m	O
by	O
15	O
m	O
by	O
10	O
m	O
was	O
defined	O
based	O
on	O

)	O
.	O

Technical	O
observations	O
High	O
grade	O
(	O
+10g/t	O
Au	O
)	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
observed	O
in	O
SDD001	O
is	O
characterised	O
by	O
multiple	O
pulses	O
of	O
auriferous	O
(	O
gold-	O
carrying	O
)	O
fluids	O
causing	O
alteration	O
and	O
deposition	O
of	O
pyrite-quartz	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
,	O
accumulating	O
gold	O
mineralisation	O
over	O
multiple	O
generations.	O
1.	O
Pulse	O
1	O
of	O
the	O
auriferous	O
fluids	O
results	O
in	O
disseminated	O
anhedral-subhedral	O
pyrite	O
(	O
±	O

chalcopyrite	O
)	O
within	O
intense	O
grey-	O
brown	O
silica-chlorite-pyrite	O
alteration	O
of	O
the	O
pale	O
grey	O
granodiorite	O
(	O
e.g.	O
232.8-234m	O
)	O
.	O

2.	O
Pulse	O
2	O
of	O
the	O
auriferous	O
fluids	O
results	O
in	O
stringer/veinlets	O
of	O
pyrite	O
(	O
±	O

chalcopyrite	O
)	O
as	O
replacement	O
in	O
intensely	O
altered	O
granitoid	O
,	O
and	O
within	O
dark	O
chlorite-biotite/amphibole	O
fracture	O
cleavage.	O
Pyrites	O
overprinted	O
on	O
early	O
stage	O
altered	O
pale	O
grey	O
granodiorite	O
with	O
disseminated	O
pyrite	O
(	O
e.g.	O
234-234.6m	O
)	O
.	O

3.	O

3	O
of	O
the	O
auriferous	O
fluids	O
results	O
in	O
blebby/stringer	O
pyrite	O
(	O
±	O

,	O
±	O

galena	O

large	O

quartz	O
veins	O
as	O
fracture	O
fill	O
(	O

235-236.4m	O
)	O
.	O

This	O
type	O
of	O
gold	O
bearing	O

(	O
±	O

Sampling	O
•	O

Nature	O
and	O
quality	O
of	O
sampling	O
(	O
eg	O
cut	O
•	O

Rock	O
chip	O
grab	O
samples	O
were	O
collected	O
from	O
outcrops	O
,	O
techniques	O
channels	O
,	O
random	O
chips	O
,	O
or	O
specific	O
specialised	O
spoil	O
heaps	O
and	O
accessible	O
surface	O
and	O
underground	O
industry	O
standard	O
measurement	O
tools	O
workings	O
of	O
quartz	O
veins	O
,	O
and	O
zones	O
of	O
silicification	O
,	O
appropriate	O
to	O
the	O
minerals	O
under	O
investigation	O
,	O
within	O
Neogene	O
volcanics	O
under	O
the	O

of	O
a	O
such	O
as	O
down	O
hole	O
gamma	O
sondes	O
,	O
or	O
qualified	O

handheld	O
XRF	O
instruments	O
,	O
etc	O
)	O
.	O

These	O
•	O

Sample	O
locations	O
were	O
surveyed	O
with	O
a	O
handheld	O
GPS	O
examples	O
should	O
not	O
be	O
taken	O
as	O
limiting	O
the	O
and	O
marked	O
into	O
sample	O
books.	O
Collar	O
locations	O
of	O
broad	O
meaning	O
of	O
sampling.	O
drillholes	O
•	O

Include	O
reference	O
to	O
measures	O
taken	O
to	O
ensure	O
sample	O
representivity	O
and	O
the	O
appropriate	O
calibration	O
of	O
any	O
measurement	O
tools	O
or	O
systems	O
used.	O
•	O

Aspects	O
of	O
the	O
determination	O
of	O
mineralisation	O
that	O
are	O
Material	O
to	O
the	O
Public	O
Report.	O
•	O

In	O
cases	O
where	O
‘	O
industry	O
standard	O
’	O
work	O
has	O
been	O
done	O
this	O
would	O
be	O
relatively	O
simple	O
(	O
eg	O
‘	O
reverse	O
circulation	O
drilling	O
was	O
used	O
to	O
obtain	O
1	O
m	O
samples	O
from	O
which	O
3	O
kg	O
was	O
pulverised	O
to	O
produce	O
a	O
30	O
g	O
charge	O
for	O
fire	O
assay	O
’	O
)	O
.	O

In	O
other	O
cases	O
more	O
explanation	O
may	O
be	O
required	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
where	O
there	O
is	O
coarse	O
gold	O
that	O
has	O
inherent	O
sampling	O
problems.	O
Unusual	O
commodities	O
or	O
mineralisation	O
types	O
(	O
eg	O
submarine	O
nodules	O
)	O
may	O
warrant	O
disclosure	O
of	O
detailed	O
information.	O
Drilling	O
•	O

Drill	O
type	O
(	O
eg	O
core	O
,	O
reverse	O
circulation	O
,	O
open-	O
•	O

Diamond	O
drilling	O
HQ3	O
and	O
NQ3	O
size	O
triple	O
tube.	O
techniques	O

Slovakia	O
has	O
a	O
known	O
mining	O
history	O
dating	O
to	O
Celtic	O
times	O
and	O
earlier.	O

used	O
by	O

at	O

Dolina	O
,	O
near	O

Bystrica	O
are	O
dated	O
as	O
early	O
as	O
2000-1700	O
BC.	O
Major	O
production	O
of	O
metals	O
(	O
primarily	O
copper	O
and	O
silver	O
)	O
occurred	O
during	O
the	O
medieval	O
period.	O
The	O
second	O
oldest	O
mining	O
institute	O
in	O
the	O
world	O
is	O
located	O
at	O
Banska	O
Stiavnica	O
and	O
the	O
local	O
population	O
is	O
proud	O
of	O
their	O
